Juana’s dreams are for her children to become professionals, to build another house, and to improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Gearhart and Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteers.

Juana pertenece al Banco Comunal Amor y Verdad hace 10 años.

Juana es casada, tiene 47 años y 9 hijos de los cuales 5 viven con ella, Juana viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región 3 veces por semana donde compra cerdos, carnero y luego lo beneficia, la venta de la carne lo realiza al por mayor en el mercado Santa Clara y también de casa en casa.

Juana necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de ganado vacuno, caprino y porcino.

Los sueños de Juana son que sus hijos sean profesionales, construir otra casa y que su negocio mejore.

loans.use: Juana needs a loan of 2000 soles (approximately $737.00 US).  This money will be invested in the purchase of cattle, goats, and pigs.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Lucia Pérez considers herself a reserved person, but very responsible and hard-working. She is married to Carlos Gómez García. They have two sons, Carlos Alberto aged 9, a primary school student, and Brenda Guadalupe, aged 3.

She started her business due to the need to increase her family’s income as her husband’s salary was already frequently not enough to make ends meet: this motivate her to establish her business.

She started-up in February 2003: she was on Vacation in the town of Reynosa, with her sister, who took her to a flea market where she had the idea of buying used or semi-new clothing in bulk to sell in Tampico in order to obtain an income. It was her sister who introduced her to a friend in Reynosa who sold stock more cheaply, and so she was able to increase her profits. She first began selling clothes alone from her house, then in a market close to where she lived and now she is established at several markets in Tampico, which has gone very well.

She is asking for a loan of $300 USD which will be repaid in 4 months in order to buy packs of used seasonal clothing which will help her to have a better variety of stock to offer to her customers and in the market.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

Lucia Pérez se considera una persona reservada pero muy responsable y trabajadora. Esta casada con el Sr. Carlos Gómez García Tienen 2 hijos Carlos Alberto de 9 años estudiante de primaria y Brenda Guadalupe de 3 años.

Inició el negocio por la necesidad de tener más ingresos familiares ya que con el sueldo de su esposo muchas veces no alcanza, esa fue la razón que la motivo a poner el negocio.

Comenzó en Febrero de 2003, estaba de vacaciones en la ciudad de Reynosa, con su hermana, la cual la llevó a un mercado rodante de los que llaman “Pulgas” y le dio la idea de comprar “pacas” de ropa usada o semi-nueva para venderla en Tampico para poder obtener un ingreso. Fue su hermana la que la presentó con una amiga en Reynosa ya que esa persona vendía mas barato y así podría obtener mayor ganancia. Primero empezó vendiendo ropa solo en su casa, después en un mercado cerca de donde vive y actualmente ya se instalo en varios mercados de Tampico y le ha ido muy bien.

Solicita un crédito por US $300 que pagara en 4 meses para adquirir pacas de ropa usada de temporada que le ayudará a tener un mayor surtido para ofrecer a sus clientes y en los mercados.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Alejandra's Group

texts.es:
Silvia, Eva, and Alejandra have belonged to the Community Bank of Love and Truth for two years, eight months, and eight years respectively.

Silvia is twenty-nine years old and married with two children. She works as an artisan with a loom, completing jobs such as making blankets in different sizes which she sells in the market F. Vivanco. Silvia and her husband also go to fairs where they sell agrochemicals, chemicals that improve the production of crops.

On the other hand, Eva is 35 years old, in a long-term relationship, and has three children. With her partner she has a workshop where they make wool “buzos,” baby clothes that cover the whole body and close with a central zipper. Eva and her partner sell their handiwork in different fairs in the Ayacucho region. Eva also sells assorted fabrics at the fairs.

Alejandra is 60 years old, married, and has 10 children, five of which live with her. She is a walking vendor who sells meat at the Nery Garcia market.

Silvia, Eva, and Alejandra need loans of 450 soles (approx. $167 US), 1250 soles (approx. $463 US), and 1000 soles (approx. $370 US) respectively. They will use the money to buy yarn, dye, wool, padlocks, batteries, sheep, and hogs.

The dreams of Silvia, Eva, and Alejandra are to improve their businesses, to increase their capital, and to see their children become skilled professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Alyssa Sanow, Anna Bevington, and Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteers

Silvia, Eva y Alejandra pertenecen al Banco Comunal Amor y Verdad hace 2 años, 8 meses, 8 años, respectivamente.

Silvia es casada, tiene 29 años y 2 hijos, Silvia es artesana, realiza trabajos en telar como frazadas en diferentes tamaños y lo venD. en el mercado F. Vivanco. Además Silvia junto a su esposo viajan a las ferias donD. venden agroquímicos.

Por otro lado Eva es conviviente, tiene 35 años y 3 hijos, Eva junto a su esposo tienen un taller donD. confeccionan buzos D. lana y los venden en las diferentes ferias D. la región D. Ayacucho. Además Eva venD. mercerías en las ferias.

Mientras que Alejandra es casada, tiene 60 años y 10 hijos D. los cuales 5 viven con ella, Alejandra venD. carne en el mercado Nery García D. manera ambulatoria.

Silvia, Eva y Alejandra necesitan préstamos D. 450 soles, 1250 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. hilo, tinte, lana, candado, pila, carnero y cerdo.

Los sueños D. Silvia, Eva y Alejandra son mejorar sus negocios, tener más capital y que sus hijos sean buenos profesionales.

loans.use: Silvia, Eva, and Alejandra need loans of 450 soles (approx. $167 US), 1250 soles (approx. $463 US), and 1000 soles (approx. $370 US) respectively. They will use the money to buy yarn, dye, wool, padlocks, batteries, sheep, and hogs.

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
Norma has belonged to the the Banco Comunal Legion for 3 years now.

Norma lives with her partner, she is 26 years old and has two children. Together with her husband, she has a restaurant called "Huan Ching," located near the Nery Garcia market. Recently, Norma opened a new restaurant on a central street of the city Ayacucho.

She needs a loan of 3,000 soles, money which will be invested in purchasing display cases and tables to be used at the new site.

Norma's dream is to have her own home, to see her businesses improve and to give her children a good education.

Translated from Spanish to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Norma pertenece al Banco Comunal Legión hace 3 años.

Norma es conviviente, tiene 26 años y 2 hijos, Norma junto a su esposo tienen un restaurante - chifa llamado “Huan Ching” ubicado cerca al mercado Nery García. Recientemente Norma aperturó un nuevo restaurante en una calle céntrica de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Norma necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de exhibidores, mesas para la implementación del nuevo local.

Los sueños de Norma son tener casa propia, sus negocios mejoren y que sus hijos tengan una buena educación.

loans.use: To purchase display cases and tables to be used in her new location.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es:
Marcela considers herself persevering, honest and very dedicated to her work. She is married to Ramón Ortiz Gilberto who works as a construction worker. She has four children: José Francisco ages 22 who is single, a student and disabled; Miriam, aged 19 and single; Celeste, aged 16, single and a high-school student and Gilberto, aged 12, a secondary-school student. They all live at home.

She established her business because she has always liked sales, and it also provided her with an independent income in order to help her husband with the household expenses. She began selling goods 20 years ago, firstly children’s underwear among her neighbours, friends and family, then she sold catalogue beauty products and from February 2004 she began to sell new clothes, which she used to sell from home but now she operates from a customised space in the front of her house and which in the future she would like to convert to a boutique.

Now she would like a loan for $300 USD which she will repay in 4 months in order to buy new seasonal clothes which will allow her to have a better stock to satisfy her customers and in this way increase her earnings.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

Marcela se considera una persona perseverante, honesta y muy dedicada a su trabajo Está casada con el Sr. Ramón Ortiz Gilberto quien trabaja como albañil. Tiene 4 hijos José Francisco de 22 años, soltero, estudiante, el es discapacitado; Miriam de 19 años, soltera; Celeste de 16 años, soltera, estudiante de preparatoria y Gilberto de 12 años, estudiante de Secundaria; todos viven en casa.

Inició el negocio porque siempre le han gustado las ventas además de que así podía obtener un ingreso aparte del de su esposo para ayudarle con los gastos de la casa. Comenzó hace 20 años en las ventas, primero con ropa interior para niño entre sus vecinas, amistades y familiares, luego se dedico a vender productos de belleza por catálogo y a partir de Febrero de 2004 inicio con la venta de ropa nueva la cual antes vendía a domicilio pero ahora ya tiene un local que acondiciono en la parte del frente de su domicilio y el cual en un futuro quiere convertir en una boutique.

Ahora solicita un préstamo por US $300 que pagará en 4 meses para comprar ropa nueva de temporada que le permita tener un mejor surtido para satisfacción de sus clientes y de esta manera aumentar sus ganancias.

loans.use: Buy Merchandise

loans.name: Petronila Susana's Group

texts.es:
Fortunita, Petronila and Hilda have belonged to the group Banco Comunal Legion for 1, 10 and 6 years, respectively.

Fortunita lives with her partner, she is 34 years old and has 4 children. Fortunita sells cosmetics through catalog orders. She also has a scooter-taxi that she rents out.

Petronila is a widow, she is 60 years old and has 5 children, she sells cheeses as a traveling saleswoman in the Santa Clara market.

Hilda is married, she is 30 years old and has two children. She travels to the markets where she sells grocery items and brings back cereals and small animals. She also has a restaurant where she works as the cook.

Fortunita, Petronila and Hilda need a loan of 1750 soles, 750 soles and 750 soles, respectively, money which will be invested in purchasing perfumes, lipglosses, creams, cheeses, sugar, rice and cereals.

The dream of these three women is to have their own restaurant, a bigger business, a stable location and to build a house.

Translated from Spanish to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Fortunita, Petronila e Hilda pertenecen al Banco Comunal Legión hace 1, 10, 6 años respectivamente.

Fortunita es conviviente, tiene 34 años y 4 hijos, Fortunita vende cosméticos al crédito por catálogos. Además Fortunita tiene un mototaxi que alquila.

Por otro lado Petronila es viuda, tiene 60 años y 5 hijos, Petronila vende quesos de manera ambulatoria en el mercado Santa Clara.

Mientras que Hilda es casada, tiene 30 años y 2 hijos, Hilda viaja a las ferias donde vende abarrotes y de las ferias trae cereales, animales menores. Además Hilda trabaja en un restaurante como cocinera.

Fortunita, Petronila e Hilda necesitan un préstamo de 1750 soles, 750 soles, 750 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de perfumes, labiales, cremas, queso, azúcar, arroz, cereales.

Los sueños de Fortunita, Petronila e Hilda son tener un restaurante propio, un negocio más grande, un puesto estable y construir su casa.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of perfumes, lipgloss, creams, cheese, sugar, rice and cereals.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 43772

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.es:
María Magdalena started her business selling new and semi-new clothes 15 years ago with a small nest-egg she had, selling a few pieces in order to improve her household’s economic situation which at that time was very precarious as her husband works in transport and earns a low salary, and also to assure a dignified future for her 3 children which at that time were adolescents and are now 30, 25 and 24 years old.

She is asking for a loan of $1150 USD which she will repay in 6 months in order to remodel her office/store space and renovate the sales area to improver the level of service offered to her customers. She trusts that with your support she will be able to make these improvements.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

María Magdalena inició el negocio de venta de ropa nueva y seminueva hace 15 años con un pequeño ahorro que tenia vendiendo pocas piezas para mejorar la situación económica en su hogar ya que en ese momento era muy precaria ya que su esposo es transportista y percibe un sueldo bajo, además de asegurar un futuro digno a sus 3 hijos, que en ese momento eran adolecentes ahora tienen 30, 25 y 24 años.

Ella solicita US $1,150 que pagara en 6 meses para remodelar su local y acondicionar un área de ventas para mejor la atención a sus clientes. Ella confía que con tu apoyo podrá realizar estas adecuaciones.

loans.use: Rennovate office/sales area

loans.name: Griselda Guadalupe

texts.es:
Griselda works selling jewellery. She started this business five years ago with some money which she had saved because she had always liked sales and it was an activity in which she had done well: she also needed extra income to help her husband with the household expenses and those of their small two children. Currently the business is doing very well.

She is asking for a loan of $775 USD which she will repay in 6 months to make renovations to her business site. With your help, Griselda will continue moving forward.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

Griselda se dedica a la venta de joyería inicio su negocio hace 5 años con algo de dinero que tenia ahorrado porque siempre le han gustado las ventas y era una actividad en la que le había ido bien, además que necesitaba un ingreso extra para apoyar a su marido con los gastos del hogar y de sus 2 pequeños hijos. Actualmente le va muy bien con este negocio.

Ella solicita un crédito por US $775 que pagara en 6 meses para hacer remodelaciones a su negocio. Con tu apoyo Griselda seguirá adelante.

loans.use: To make renovations

loans.name: Sugeng

texts.id:
Pria aged 38 has 2 children had already made prior business development funding loan with a fixed installment repayment until settled. This intention is to use this second loan as additional capital for the fried products business carried out currently. The obstacle faced currently is the increasing cost of raw materials, which influenced the ability to buy. Because of that Sugeng needed this additional business funding. As a matter of fact, Sugeng also runs a side business, as installer of advertisements and billboards but the income is minimal and usually sporadic, not consistently. Sugeng currently live on Pulau Pinang road in a rented room and owns a motorcycle as her day-to-day transport.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Pria berumur 38 tahun yang memiliki 2 orang anak ini sebelumnya sudah pernah meminjam dana pengembangan usaha dengan angsuran yang tepat waktu sampai lunas. Pinjaman yang ke-2 ini rencananya akan digunakan sebagai tambahan modal usaha gorengan yang dijalaninya saat ini. Kendala yang dihadapi saat ini adalah naiknya harga dasar bahan baku yang berpengaruh pada menurunnya daya beli. Oleh karena itu Sugeng sangat membutuhkan tambahan modal usaha ini. Sebenarnya Sugeng juga memiliki usaha sampingan sebagai tenaga pemasang iklan dan baliho tetapi pendapatannya sangat minim dan itupun hanya sesekali saja, tidak terus menerus. Sugeng sekarang ini tinggal di jalan Pulau Pinang dengan menyewa sebuah kamar dan memiliki sepeda motor sebagai alat transportasinya sehari-hari.

loans.use: Increase Working Capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Eng

texts.en: Mrs. Eng K. S., 37, is married with two children and lives with her husband in a part of Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She has a stand at a market, where she sells porridge and Chinese noodles for breakfast. Eng K. S. and her husband have to get up very early in the morning to cook all their food stuffs and send them to the market. When everything is done and well-prepared Mrs. Eng K. S. works selling all the food stuffs at the market and her husband goes back home to breed their cows. With her business activity, Mrs. Eng K. S. can typically makes $15 each day in income, of which one part of the money is for repaying her loan and another part of the money is used to cover her family’s expenses. Recently, Mrs. Eng K. S. applied for a loan to help her expand her business. She lacks utensils and some equipment. The rest of the loan she also wants to beneficially use to purchase more calves for her family’s livestock.

loans.use: To purchase utensils and equipment for her stand

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Mrs. Ly P., 28, is married with two school-aged children and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She works selling fish and Khmer noodles on the road side of her village, making on average around $2.50 per day of net income. Her husband is a carpenter and typically makes about $2.50 each day too. Mrs. Ly P. has lately requested a loan to purchase more fish to expand her inventory and the remainder of the loan she would like to use to buy a motor-bike to use for business transportation. (She is pictured with a motor-bike she hopes to buy.)

loans.use: To purchase a motor-bike to use for business transportation

loans.name: Ni Ketut Darmini

texts.id:
Darmini’s store opens daily at 9 am. Many customers visit her store. Darmini store is in front of her house. Goods available are purchased from the main market in the city. Every third day, Darmini buys goods for sale. The funding required for purchasing merchandise in 3 days amount to Rp. 3.500.000.- (about USD400) and income generated daily is Rp. 35.000.- (about USD4). Her store opens till 10 pm. Only her husband assists Darmini who supports this business tremendously. The income earned will supplement the payment of the family’s expenses. Darmini’s future plan is to further develop her business so as to increase the customers buying her merchandise.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Usaha Warung Darmini dibuka setiap pukul 09.00 pagi. Warung Darmini ramai dikunjungi pelanggan. Darmini membuka warung didepan rumahnya. Barang yang didapat dibeli dipasar besar di kotanya. Setiap 3 hari sekali Darmini membeli barang untuk dijual. Modal yang diperlukan untuk membeli bahan jualannya dalam 3 hari Sebesar Rp. 3.500.000.- dan mendapat keuntungan perhari Rp. 35.000.- Warung ini dibuka sampai pukul 10.00 malam. Darmini hanya dibantu oleh suami yang sangat mendukung dalam usaha ini. Keuntungan yang didapat sangat membantu kebutuhan rumah tangganya. Untuk rencana kedepannya Darmini ingin lebih mengembangkan usahanya agar lebih banyak pelanggan yang membeli barang dagangannya.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise to equip her store (Membeli barang dagangan untuk melengkapi warungnya)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Ni Luh Deli

texts.id:
Being a cow breeder is an activity is not left out of Niluh Deli. Her husband also helps in this activity. Collecting grass for the calves is one of the works frequently performed by her husband. They mutually agree to cooperate, that is one work that needs to be attended to. Everyday at 6 am already busy providing grass feed which is readied for early evening; while mid-day they are left in the yard to seek their own food, approaching night at 6 pm again busy feeding the calves. This activity is carried out so that the calves reared will be fat and healthy, finished green supplies is not lacking in the village but need to seek in the area surrounding the village, income maybe little nevertheless can aid and increase income for the family.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Menjadi peternak sapi adalah suatu kegiatan yang tidak pernah ditinggalkan Niluh Deli.Suami juga membatu dalam usaha ini.Mencari rumput untuk sapinya adalah suatu pekerjaan yang sering dilakukan oleh suami Deli.Mereka sepakat untuk saling kerjasama, itu adalah suatu pekerjaan yang sudah ditekuninya. Setiap hari pukul 6.00 pagi sudah sibuk memberi makan rumput yang sudah dipersiapkan sore harinya.sedang untuk siang hari dibiarkan di kebunnya untuk mencari makan sendiri.menjelang malam hari pukul 6.00 sore juga sibuk untuk memberi makan sapinya. Kegiatan ini dilakukan dengan harapan sapi peliharaannya bisa gemuk dan sehat.persediaan pakan hijauan tidak pernah kekurangan didesanya asal mau mencarinya di daerah sekitar desanya. penghasilan memang sedikit namun bisa untuk membantu dan menambah pendapatan bagi keluarganya.

loans.use: Purchase calves and supplies (Membeli anak sapi dan pakan)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ni Putu Karyawati

texts.id:
Every 9 am Karyawati feeds the 2 pigs being raised. This work has become daily routine after completing cooking in the kitchen. The bamboo pen owned behind the house has become a place for the pigs being raised. This effort greatly assists in meeting the family’s expenses. Karyawati has 2 children under her responsibility. Her enthusiasm for this effort eases her husband because it lightens his burden as the head of the household. Income, which was realized, is very satisfying, in 6 months 2 piglets will generate Rp. 800.000.- (about USD90) net. This income is used for paying the children’s education and is very supportive of their life.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Setiap pukul 09:00 wita Karyawati memberi makan 2 ekor babi peliharaannya.Pekerjaan ini tentunya sudah menjadi rutinitas kesehariaannya setelah selesai memasak didapur. Kandang bambu yang dimiliki dibelakang rumah,sebagai tempat untuk menampung babi yang dipelihara. Usaha ini sangat membantu dalam memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya. Karyawati memiliki dua orang anak yang masih menjadi tanggungan. Semangat untuk berusaha yang dimilki membuat suaminya sangat senang karena sangat meringankan beban sebagai bapak kepala rumah tangga. Keuntungan yang sudah dirasakan sangat memuaskan.dalam 6 bulan 2 bibit babi ini bisa menghasilkan Rp.800.000,- bersih. Keuntungan ini digunakan untuk biaya sekolah anaknya dan sangat menunjang kehidupannya.

loans.use: Purchase breeding supplies (Membeli pakan ternak)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Eim

texts.en:
Mrs. Eim P., 53, is a farmer in Kampong Svay Village and she has three children, two of whom work in a factory while the other looks after cows. Her husband, Chhieng Pal, is also a subsistence farmer who usually cultivates the field with his wife. The family income is generated from cultivating and selling bananas and from the children's salary.

So far Mrs. Em P. has been funded by other MFIs and she got loans to cultivate rice. Last year she was ill and she spent around $12 per time on medicines. Presently, she is in good health and can work again; however, her cultivatable land is not fertile and thus she needs to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers to support the field. Her husband is on the left on the photo.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer.

loans.name: Ni Ketut Yastrini

texts.id:
Ketut Yastrini owns a store, which she had operated diligently since. Having married 7 years, Yastrini has not been blessed with a child. Her husband worked as a farmer. Everyday Yastrini commences her work from 4 am. After waking Yastrini is ready to go to morning main market, to purchase merchandise for her store. Returning home by 5 am, cooks fish, prepares rice, boils vegetables, prepares bananas, and finally prepares sweet ice. Yastrini besides making cooked food also sells basic needs. Loan from Dinari Rp. 3.500.000,- (about USD400) will all be used for merchandise for the store. Prior to this loan from Dinari income earned daily was Rp. 25.000,- to Rp. 30.000,- (about USD3.50). With this loan the daily income is Rp. 30.000,- to Rp. 60.000,- (about USD6). With this income Yastrini assist in meeting the family’s expenses.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Ketut Yastrini memiliki usaha warung yang sudah lama ditekuninya.Sudah 7 Tahun menikah Yastrini belum juga dikaruniai anak. Suami Yastrini bekerja sebagai petani. Setiap hari Yastrini memulai usahanya mulai jam 4.00 pagi. Bangun tidurYastrini sudah bersiap –siap untuk pergi ke pasar pagi di Negara. membeli semua kebutuhan warungnya . Sampai dirumah jam 5.00 pagi , mulai memasak ikan, membuat nasi, merebus tipat, merebus sayur,membuat kolak pisang, dan terakhir membuat gula es. Yastrini selain membuat makanan matang juga menjual Sembako. Modal yang di pinjam dari Dinari Rp.3.500.000,- semua sudah dipergunakan untuk kebutuhan warungnya. Sebelum pinjam dari Dinari keuntungan yang di dapat perhari Rp.25.000,- sd Rp.30.000,-. Setelah pinjam dari Dinari keuntungan perhari Rp.30.000,- sd Rp.60.000,-. Dengan keuntungan ini Yastrini membantu kebutuhan rumah tangganya.

loans.use: Purchase raw merchandise (Membeli barang dagangan)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Phoung

texts.en:
Mrs. Phoung S. was born in 1946 and she is married with Mr. Morn Yong who is a farmer. Mrs. Phoung S. is also a farmer in Kaoh Prak Village in Kandal Province and the mother of four children, two of whom are working in garment factory while the others are enrolled in school.

Last year, she faced a problem with floods which made her crop decline so she could generate only a very small income. At the same time her family also got sick; her husband had a stomachache and heart disease and they spent around $100 each time on treatment. However, the family now is in good health and they can work.

Mrs. Phoung S.’s field is dry and not fertile any longer, thus she would like to apply for a loan to buy a pump. The rest she would use to purchase fertilizer to support the field. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a pump and fertilizer.

loans.name: Titik

texts.id:
This is Titik's 2nd loan. She borrowed some money before and she never fails the installment payment schedules. Her cakes business is actually quite smooth, however recently the prices of ingredients are going up and therefore she needs extra money for her working capital.

She sells her cakes by consign them at local cakes stores such as Orange bakery and Merdeka cake shop. A mother of two children, Titik has to make her business running in the midst of inflation. One of her ways to deal with inflation is to make her cakes smaller.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Pinjaman ini merupakan pinjaman yang ke-2. Sebelumnya Titik pernah meminjam dengan angsuran yang teratur, tidak pernah terlambat. Usaha jualan kue yang dijalaninya sebenarnya berjalan cukup lancar, hanya saja karena kendala harga bahan baku kue yang terus naik, maka Titik membutuhkan tambahan modal untuk usahanya. Kesehariannya Titik menitipkan kue-kue bikinannya di toko-toko sekitar Jl.Teuku Umar seperti Toko Orange dan Toko Merdeka. Ibu dari Aprizal dan Farrel ini sekarang harus bisa bertahan meskipun harga semua bahan pokok naik. Caranya adalah dengan memperkecil ukuran kue bikinannya. Saat ini Titik tinggal di Jl. Pulau Pinang bersama suami dan ke-2 anaknya.

loans.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Rohadiah

texts.id:
Rohadiah is a used goods collector. She has been in this business for quite a while. She goes for work twice a day from 06.00 am - 09.00 am and from 03.00 p.m. - 05.30 p.m. She looks for used goods such as can, papers, glasses to be later sold at recycle centers.

She can earn money from this job and she can send money to her parents who live in Java island. She also uses the money to send her child to Junior High School.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Usaha mengumpulkan barang bekas sudah sejak lama dilakoni oleh Rohadiah. Ia biasa berangkat 2 kali sehari, dari pukul 06.00 sampai 09.00. Setelah istrahat sebentar Ia mulai menyortir hasil krongsokannya karena harus dipisahkan antara kaleng, kertas dan gelas/botol air mineral. Sore hari Ia berangkat pukul 15.00 sampai 17.30. Dari hasil menjual rongsokan Ia bisa menyambung hidupnya di bali bahkan dikirim untuk orangtuanya yang ada di Jawa dan juga dipakai untuk biaya pendidikan anak yang sekarang duduk di bangku SMP.

loans.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Rohadiah

texts.id: Usaha mengumpulkan barang bekas sudah sejak lama dilakoni oleh Rohadiah.  Ia biasa berangkat 2 kali sehari, dari pukul 06.00 sampai 09.00. Setelah istrahat sebentar Ia mulai menyortir hasil krongsokannya karena harus dipisahkan antara kaleng, kertas dan gelas/botol air mineral. Sore hari Ia berangkat pukul 15.00 sampai 17.30. Dari hasil menjual rongsokan Ia bisa menyambung hidupnya di bali bahkan dikirim untuk orangtuanya yang ada di Jawa dan juga dipakai untuk biaya pendidikan anak yang sekarang duduk di bangku SMP.

loans.use: Menambah Modal Usaha

loans.name: Sophat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophat S. and her husband, Mr. Morn Moe, married in 1984. They have five children; three sons and two daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. Of the other three children, one is employed full time, one is in school, and the youngest one stays at home. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sophat and her husband have been fishing for a living for over ten years. They fish in the Mekong River and sell to retailers at the market in Phnom Penh. 

She is requesting a loan of $500 to repair some parts of her house.

loans.use: to repair her house

loans.name: Chanlach

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanlach H., 48, and her husband married in 1978. They have nine children; six sons and three daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. One of their children weaves silk at home, two are employed full time and the other four are students. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Chanlach has been a silk weaver for over ten years. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who will then sell them in Phnom Penh. Her family has two looms. Her husband is a worker. 

She is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase materials for weaving silk.

loans.use: to purchase materials for weaving silk

loans.name: Sophois

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophois C. and her husband married in 1997. They have four children; three sons and one daughter.  They are all in school. The family lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sophois has been selling fish for eight years. She purchases them from a fish wholesaler at Ta Kmao market. Her husband is a policeman who operates a motor taxi in his spare time.

Mrs. Sophois is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase fish to resell.

loans.use: to purchasing fish for resale

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Mrs. Rin A. is a widow with five children; two sons and three daughters. Some of her children are in school and others are employed full time. The family lives about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Rin has been selling fish for over three years. She purchases them from a fish wholesaler at Ta Kmao market and resells them at the village market. She is requesting a loan of $700 to build a restroom for her family's use.

loans.use: to build a restroom for family's use

loans.name: Savin

texts.en:
Mrs. Savin L. and her husband have been married since 1994. They have three children; two sons and one daughter. All of their children are in school. The family lives along the Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Savin has been a silk weaver for eight years. It’s a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who will then sell them in Phnom Penh.  Her husband has also been a silk weaver for seven years.  


She is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase materials for weaving silk.  Based on her business success so far, she will have no problem in repaying the loan to MAXIMA.

loans.use: to purchase material for weaving silk

loans.name: Sri

texts.id:
Mrs Sri I., 42 years old, sells foods which are categorized as "Sembako" or nine basic necessities. This business is quite good as she has a lot of customers from her neighbors. Twice a week she buys her merchandises from Badung Market. Her eldest son usually drives her to the market in a motorcycle.

She wants to use the loan money to expand her Sembako business.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Ibu Sri I. mulai menekuni usaha jual Sembako sejak tahun 2000. Usahanya cukup lancar karena disekitar tempat tinggalnya hanya dia yang berjualan dan biasanya konsumennya adalah mereka yang kost disekitar tempat itu. Dua (2) seminggu dia belanja bahan-bahan di Pasar Badung, dan biasanya dia diantar oleh anak sulungnya menggunakan sepeda motor. Ibu berusia 42 tahun ini bisa membiayai kebutuhan keluarganya dan juga pendidikan anaknya dengan keuntungan dari jualan Sembako. Ibu Sri I. sangat mengharapkan bantuan modal usaha untuk pengembangan toko Sembako miliknya.

loans.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Chun

texts.en:
Chun B. is 38 years old and with her three children, has resided in Kampong Cham province for many years. All her children are students and sometimes, when they have free time, they help their mother selling sugar cane juice and groceries. On average, she earns around $6 a day of profit. She started the business in the year 2000. Moreover, to support the family’s income her husband, Kun Sopheap, 43, is a police official with a salary of $50 per month.

Because she wants to increase the number of groceries for sale to meet her customer's demand, she has applied for a loan from Kiva, to purchase groceries in bulk and save the money. The majority of the loan will however be used to purchase a plot of land to resell whenever the price is high.

loans.use: To purchase groceries and land

loans.name: Khat

texts.en:
Khat L., age 53, is a widow with four children. She works to cover the daily expenses by selling food and rice to customers. She makes on average about $6 a day of profit. Two of her children are students and the rest help her mother.

To help the family make more disposable income, she needs to borrow some money to purchase a plot of land to resell when the price goes up, to make a profit. With the remainder, she will invest in her existing business to meet her customer’s demand. (Mrs. Khat L. is pictured with her daughter.)

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land to resell

loans.name: Salelologa Tumupapa Centre - Group 3

texts.en:
Miranda T., 25, is married to a laborer and has three children. She is starting a business selling taro. Her husband will do the farming. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, two bush knives, a filing, and 1,500 taro roots. She will sell her produce one day a week and plans to earn a net weekly cash flow of 120 Tala (~48 USD).

Galegale A., 26, is single with no children. For over two years, she has sold taro, bananas, and yams in the Salelologa market on Fridays. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, four knives, two filings, and a spade. With this expansion, she expects to earn net cash flow per week of 100 Tala (~ 40 USD).

loans.use: Purchase a weed killer, pesticides, 2 bush knives, etc.

loans.name: Norng

texts.en: Mrs. Norng L., age 51, is a mother of two children. She has lived in Phnom Penh over 20 years. She is a house wife who stays at home, looks after the children, and cooks food for the famiL. members. Her husband, Chan Yong, 43, has been a motor-taxi driver since 2002. NormalL. he makes around $3 a day. Their children are learning very hard and they always are admired for their hard work by their teacher. Seeing this, Norng L., realL. wants her children have a bachelor's degree in the near future in order to have a better job when they finish school. So to encourage them to study hard, she is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a computer to assist them with their class work. (Her husband is pictured because Mrs. Norng L. is not available.)

loans.use: To purchase a computer for her children

loans.name: Pon

texts.en: Pon T. is 40 years old and has been working since 1990 as a collector of recyclable items. She makes her living by reselling these bottles, cans, and other such recyclables bringing in roughly US $1 per day. Her husband shares in this family business making US $1 per day as well. They have four children, one of whom works as a local tailor making about US $189 per month. She wants to use her loan to buy a greater quantity of recyclable items. Her hope is to be able to someday soon afford a motorbike on which to transport her purchased goods and make her business more efficient.

loans.use: To purchase recyclable items

loans.name: Fusi Safotulafai Centre - Group 2

texts.en:
For these 5 women of Fusi Safotulafai Centre on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments, and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

Motu Mataitoga T., 49, is married with 7 children. She is entering the taro business. Her family has a history of farming but not for sale. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a filing, and 2,500 taro roots.

Tufaiga A., 35, is married to a farmer and has 6 children. She and her husband have farmed a taro plantation for over 5 years. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a bush knife, a filing, and an axe. She plans to earn 120 Tala (~48 USD) per week in net cash flow by selling her taro at the Salelologa market.

Faasalafa V., 48, is married with 4 children. She and her husband have farmed a taro plantation for over 3 years. With her loan, she will purchase pesticides, a bush knife, and a spade. She plans to earn 300 Tala (~120 USD) per week in net cash flow by selling her taro at the Salelologa market.

Silia S., 59, has 2 children and is married to a farmer. She is starting a business selling pancakes (deep fried pieces of dough) and ice cakes (ice cream). With her loan, she will purchase 2 bags of flour, 2 bags of sugar, 2 bags of yeast, 2 cans of cooking oil, and 4 plastic cups. She will sell her food 5 days a week in her village, at the school and to passersby.

Eleoupu P., 43, is married with 4 children. She has over 2 years of experience in taro farming. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a knife, and a filing, and also hire 5 workers.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for taro farming, including weed killer, pesticides, tools, and taro roots

loans.name: Iva B Centre - Group 3

texts.en:
For these 3 women of Iva B on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

Silivia Wong S., 40, is married to a carpenter and has 7 children. For over 2 years, she has farmed a taro plantation. She employs 5 workers. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, fertilizer, a bush knife, and labor.

Mua Ee V., 36, has 4 children and is married to a farmer. She is involved in 2 businesses: farming and fishing. She sells taro one day per week at the Salelologa market and sells fish three days per week. He husband performs the farming and fishing duties. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a lantern and a fishing boat.

Naoupu Lefee M., 47, is married to a farmer and fisherman. She has 4 children. She has over 3 years of experience in taro farming. She will use her loan to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a knife, a filing and 1,000 taro roots.

loans.use: Purchase a weed killer, pesticides, fishing boat…

loans.name: Nhom Co Huan - Thon Duc Lan - Xa Yen Phu Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. C. Thị Huân (MS 13050021), 48 years old, married with two school age children, is an industrious woman. She farms, raises poultry and sells chicken eggs. She has never had a loan before. She is applying for a loan of 2006000 đồng, that’d paid off in 6 months, T. invest in her chickens. With her current income of 300.000 đồng a week, she won’t have problem with the repayment plan. Her group has 4 other members. They all apply for loans of the same amount as hers.
  • Tô Thị Vụ (MS 13050022), 41 years old, applies for a loan T. invest in her fruit stand
  • C. Thị Chén (MS 13050023), 57 years old, applies for a loan T. buy feed for pigs
  • C. Thị Hợi (MS 13050024), 37 years old, applies for a loan T. invest in her chicken eggs business
  • Trần Thị Bình (MS13050026), 33 years old, applies for a loan T. buy feed for pigs.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Cô C. Thị Huân (MS 13050021), 48 tuổi, đang sống cùng chồng và hai con đang đi học. Cô rất chăm chỉ làm nhiều việc để phát triển kinh tế gia đình như: làm ruộng, nuôi gà đẻ trứng và buôn bán các loại trứng gà. Cô chưa từng vay ở đâu, nay tham gia chương trình Tài chính Vi mô Bình minh với mức vay 2006000 đồng, kỳ hạn 6 tháng để bổ xung vốn mua gà giống. Với thu nhập 300.000 đồng/tuần cô tin rằng mình sẽ dễ dàng tiết kiệm để hoàn trả hàng tuần. Các thành viên trong nhóm cô là: Chị Tô Thị Vụ (MS 13050022), 41 tuổi, vay vốn để thêm vốn chợ hoa quả Chị C. Thị Chén (MS 13050023), 57 tuổi, vay vốn mua cám lợn Chị C. Thị Hợi (MS 13050024), 37 tuổi, vay vốn thêm vốn buôn bán trứng Chị Trần Thị Bình (MS13050026), 33 tuổi, vay vốn để mua cám lợn

loans.use: Invest in various businesses

loans.name: Pisa

texts.en: Pisa A., 44, is married to a farmer and they have 5 children together.  She is wishing to enter the taro selling business.  She will use her loan to purchase 2 bush knives, 2 knife filings, and 2,500 taro roots.

loans.use: Purchase knives, filings and taro roots

loans.name: Salelologa Sapulu Centre - Group 2

texts.en:
For these 3 women of Salelologa Sapulu on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

Vasati P., 42, is divorced with 3 children. She has over 2 years experience in sewing. She sews t-shirts, uniforms and puletasis (dresses). Her loan will be used to purchase a sewing machine, material, thread and other items. She will sell her clothing 5 days per week.

Tiotala S., 56, is married with 5 children. Her husband is a fisherman and a farmer. She has over 3 years of experience farming taro. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, and 2,000 taro roots.

Sina M., 67, is married with 6 children. Her husband is unable to work because of sickness. She is helping her son start a hair salon. With her loan, she will purchase clippers, scissors, a comb, a mirror, shelves, and a chair.

loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine, material, thread, etc.

loans.name: Nhom Chi Tham - Thon An Ninh Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Hồng Thắm (MS 13010027), 23 years old, is married with two small children. The coupL. are young and active. He is a truck driver and she tends a grocery stand. They have a loan, almost paid off, with the agricultural bank to buy his truck. She is applying for a loan of 2006000 đồng, that’d paid off in 6 months, to invest in her grocery stand. Her group has 5 other members. They all apply for loans of the same amount as hers.
  • Lê Thị Mận (MS 13010028), 34 years old, applies for a loan to buy fabrics
  • Nguyễn Thị Sáu (MS 13010029), 41 years old, applies for a loan to buy feed for pigs
  • Nguyễn Thị Năm (MS 13010031), 44 years old, applies for a loan to buy feed for pigs
  • C. Thị Liên (MS 13010032), 21 years old, applies for a loan to invest in “đi chợ”
  • Nguyễn Thị Thơm (MS 13010033) applies for a loan to to invest in “đi chợ”

Đi chợ, a general Vietnamese term, describes the everyday trading activity of small items at village open market. Traders seek opportunity to buy items which can be resold to others at a minimal profit. These items can be anything, including products such as a littL. fish or a small bundL. of vegetables. At times the Traders don't have a stand, but rather sell their wares directly from their person.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Nguyễn Thị Hồng Thắm (MS 13010027), 23 tuổi, có 2 con nhỏ. Vợ chồng chị dù rất trẻ nhưng khá chăm chỉ, năng động. Chồng chị là lái xe ô tô, vợ bán các mặt hàng tạp hoá. Anh chị đã từng vay vốn ở ngân hàng nông nghiệp để mua ô tô cho chồng lái xe chở hàng thuê nhưng đã hoàn trả gần hết nợ. Chi tham gia Tài chính vi mô bình minh để thêm vốn mua hàng tạp hoá bán. Chị vay mức 2006000đồng với kỳ hạn là 6 tháng. Các thành viên khác: Chị Lê Thị Mận (MS 13010028), 34 tuổi, vay vốn để mua vải may quần áo Chị Nguyễn Thị Sáu (MS 13010029), 41 tuổi, vay vốn để mua cám lợn Chị Nguyễn Thị Năm (MS 13010031), 44 tuổi, vay vốn đế mua cám lợn Chị C. Thị Liên (MS 13010032), 21 tuổi, vay vốn để đi chợ Chị Nguyễn Thị Thơm (MS 13010033, vay vốn để đi chợ.

loans.use: Invest in various businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia T., 20, is married to a farmer.  She is entering the business of selling taro.  Both she and her husband will do the farming.  With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, 2 bush knives, 2 filings, seeds, pumpkins, and fertilizer.

loans.use: Purchase a weed killer, pesticides, 2 bush knives, etc.

loans.name: Saasaai 2 Centre - Group 3

texts.en:
For these 3 women of Saasaai 2 on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

Aussie F., 18, is married with 1 child. She is starting a bakery business. With her loan, she will purchase cement, metal, and iron roofing to construct an oven. Also, she will purchase oil, flour, sugar, and other ingredients to make pies, biscuits, buns, and other baked goods.

Asolelei T., 39, is married with 7 children. She grows taro, yams, bananas, and other vegetable and fruit produce. Although her family has been doing it for many years, this is her first business selling produce. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a filing, 2 bow knives, and fertilizer.

Teuila L., 46, is married with 11 children. Her sons help her farm her taro and yam plantation. With her loan, she will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, fertilizer, cabbage seeds, and a license. She will sell her produce 5 days per week.

loans.use: Purchase supplies to start a bakery and for farming

loans.name: Fusi Safotulafai Centre - Group 1

texts.en:
For these 7 women of Fusi Safotulafai mupapa on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business, maintaining a savings account and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

The women will use their loans for the following purposes:

See K. (49, married, 3 children) will purchase fertilizer, pesticides, a weed killer, a bush knife, and a knife filing for her taro business.

Palota F. (41, married, 3 children) will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a bush knife, a knife filing, a spade, and an axe for her taro business.

Pelo P. (53, divorced, 3 children) will purchase flour, sugar, oil, yeast, a deep fryer, and gas to cook pancakes for sale.

Silivia K. (49, married, 4 children) will purchase a fishing net, a torch, goggles, a spear, and bait for her fishing business.

Pipiana P. (32, married, 1 child) will purchase a weed killer, pesticides, fertilizer, a filing, and a bush knife for her taro business.

Faasu F. (20, married, 1 child) will purchase a weed killer, fertilizer, pesticides, a bush knife, a filing, and an axe.

Irene I. (30, married, 2 children) will purchase a weed killer, fertilizer, pesticides, a bush knife and a filing.

loans.use: Purchase a weed killer, pesticides, fertilizer, a filing, etc

loans.name: Faamita

texts.en: Faamita M., 32, is married with 3 children.  She has over 2 years of experience selling baked goods and growing vegetables.  She wishes to buy supplies to expand both of her businesses.  Specifically, she will purchase flour, sugar, oil, yeast, pesticides, and a weed killing sprayer.

loans.use: Purchase a weed killer and pesticides

loans.name: Saletagaloa Salelologa Centre - Group 1

texts.en:
For these 11 women of Saletagaloa Salelologa on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

The women will use their loans for the following purposes:

Faaiviivi F. (54, married, 5 children) to purchase a spade, pesticides, knives, a planting stick, a filing, and a wheelbarrow for her fruit and vegetable (taro, yam, cocoa, bananas and other produce) business.

Luisa I. (43, married, 5 children) to purchase chemicals, knives, weed killer, a sack of sugar, plastic, and concentrate for her vegetable (taro and banana) and ice cake (ice cream) businesses.

Nive F. S. (21, married, 1 child) to purchase chicken legs, corned beef, fish, spam, noodles, sugar, rice cheese, gel, tea, and other items for her retail shop.

Ana E. (52, married, 8 children) to purchase pesticides, a knife and a wheel barrow for her fruit and vegetable (taro, bananas, cucumbers, pumpkins and tomatoes) business.

Tusiga T. (54, married) to purchase a fishing net, a hook and a spear for her fish business.

Malie S. (42, divorced, 6 children) to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, 2 bush knives, and a knife filing.

Pelita F. (62, married, 9 children) to purchase pesticides, fertilizer, a wheel barrow, seeds, and a bush knife for her fruit and vegetable (cabbages, tomatoes, cucumbers) business.

Mema Tautua (50, married, 6 children) to purchase fertilizer, a filing, a knife, pesticides, and a fishing net for her taro and fish businesses.

Lulu T. (34, married, 4 children) to purchase an elei board, x-ray designs, brushes, threads, material, paints and shelves for her clothing business.

Rosa F. P. (28, married, 2 children) to purchase barbed wires, rice, nails, hammer, and knives to raise chicken chickens and make handbags.

Siutu L. (21, married, 3 children) to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, planting stick, a knife, a filing, and a spade.

loans.use: Purchase a weed killer, pesticides, fertilizer, a filing, etc

loans.name: Fatma's Tusichukiane Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 40 years old and is a widow with 2 children, ages 25 and 22 years old. Fatma has been selling charcoal and fish since 2007. Every day, she works from 4m to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Fatma now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have small businesses.The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Salelologa Sapulu Centre - Group 1

For these 8 women of Salelologa Sapulu on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

The women will use their loans for the following purposes:

Faimafili M. (44, married, 11 children) to purchase a fishing boat, a fishing net, goggles, and a spear for her fish business.

Iutita S. (28, married) to purchase a sewing machine for her clothing business.

Eseta S. (29, married, 2 children) to purchase a cooler, a box of cups, pesticides, a bag of sugar, and candy for her ice cake (ice cream) business.

Alofa T. M. (30, married, 3 children) to purchase timber, iron roofing, and cement to build her barber shop.

Sialia T. F. (59, married, 4 children) to purchase oil, a gas oven, large pots, and plastic cups for her popcorn and clothing businesses.

Fualole A. (26, married, 1 child) to purchase concentrate, sugar, plastic cups, candy, and a cooler for her ice cake business.

Faoliu M S. (43, single, 2 children) to purchase an oven, flour, sugar, pork, and other items for her pork and bread business.

Panou M. (47, married, 5 children) to purchase sugar, flour, butter, eggs, yeast, and cement and timber to build her bakery which sells donuts, pork cakes and bread.

loans.name: Asha's Tusichukiane Group

texts.en:
Asha is 22 years old and is a single woman. Asha owns a small tailoring shop, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

Asha now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have small businesses.The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Chuob

texts.en:
Chuob T., age 47, lives with her husband and eight children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She has a business selling groceries and earns around $1.5 a day of profit. Her husband, Sao Cheo, 48, is a construction worker building a house. He makes around $1 of profit per day. One son is a construction worker like his father and earns around $1.5 a day and two of their daughters are employed as garment factory workers with a salary of $70 each per month. The rest of their children are students.

To make the family's standard of living better and reduce the cost of commuting to work, Chuob T. would like to take a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for her daughters to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her daughters for commute to work

loans.name: Tafua Tai Centre - Group 1

texts.en:
For these 6 women of Tafua Tai on the island of Savaii, these are their first loans from SPBD. They all undertook 4 weeks of training on managing a business and maintaining a savings account, and then passed a written test on the SPBD principles: business, savings, weekly meetings, payments and group guarantee. Over the next 52 weeks, they will support each other in their individual business development and to guarantee on-time payments.

The women will use their loans for the following purposes:

Saloaloa M. (58, married, 8 children) to purchase tools, mats, and other materials to create handicrafts.

Afiafi L. (58, single, 2 children) to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, taro roots, laborers, 2 knives, and BBQ supplies for her BBQ and produce (taro, bananas, etc) businesses.

Potoae L. (62, widow, 4 children) to pay for a wheelbarrow, laborers, knives, a filing, and other items for her produce (yam, taro, banana, coconut, etc) business.

Sui L. (31, married, 1 child) to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, 2 knives, a knife filing, an axe, laborers, and taro roots for her produce (taro, yam, and banana) business.

Faaiulotu F. (44, widow, 6 children) to purchase a weed killer, pesticides, a knife, and taro roots for her produce (taro, yam, bananas, etc) business.

Elisapeta M. (26, married, 1 child) to purchase an elei board, brushes, materials and pains for her Elei painted sarongs, dresses and t-shirts.

loans.use: Purchase tools to make handicrafts and farming

loans.name: Moli's Tusichukiane Group

texts.en:
Moli is 34 years old and is divorced with 2 children, ages 13 and 7 years old. Moli has been selling fish since 2006. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Moli now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have small businesses.The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Lach

texts.en: Lach K., age 29, is a young mother of three children and has lived in Kampong Cham province for many years. She works making Khmer cake and has been selling them at the market since 2006, normally earning around $1.5 a day of profit. Her husband works making cutting boards. In Cambodia, usually all the cutting boards are made from wood. He receives $4 a day for his work. To make more profits, the couple would like to take a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike and trailer to run a new business. This will give them extra income to support the household. (Picture is of husband and wife.)

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and trailer

loans.name: Kazija's Tusichukiane Group

texts.en:
Kazija is 38 years old and is married with 7 children, ages 12 to 20 years old. Kazija has been a food supplier since 2005. Every day, she works from 7am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Kazija now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have small businesses. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma is 44 years old and is divorced with 4 children, ages 24, 22, 20 and 14 years old. She also takes care of 4 other children, ages 1-6 years old. Salma sells mobiles, perfumes, clothes and shoes starting in 1992. Everyday, she works from 7am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $400 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items (mobiles, perfumes, clothes and shoes) for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items  for her business.

loans.name: Try

texts.en:
Mrs. Try M., age 42, is married with six children and resides in Kampong Cham province with her husband of many years. She and her husband, Ek Sam Eoeun, 44, work to raise the family’s income by making cutting boards and selling them to the market to earn approximately $2.5 of profit per day. One child is a construction worker building a house and makes about $2 a day.
This couple would like to request a loan from Kiva to purchase cashew nuts to stock and resell for profit.

loans.use: To purchase cashew nuts to stock

loans.name: Asha's Hatuchoki Group

texts.en:
Asha is 37 years old and is divorced with 3 children, ages 17, 14, and 3 years old. She also takes care of 2 other children, ages 26 and 20 years old. Asha began her business in 1998; today she conducts a mobile phone business and also sells soup. Every day, she works from 7am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Asha now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who also has a small business. The members mutuA. guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other member is responsible.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma is 34 years old and is married with 4 children, ages 9 months to 12 years old. She and her husband also take care of 1 other person, who is 56 years old. Mwajuma owns a small charcoal store, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Mwajuma now hopes for a loan to buy charcoal for her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Siti

texts.id:
Mrs. Siti A. is a food vendor. She sells mixed rice (fast food). Her food stall is located at Kupaon street, which is one of the main street in Bali as it is the main intersection for tourist hot spots such as Sanur, Kuta and Nusa Dua. She lives with her husband in a rented room.

She wakes up at 04.00 am everyday to start her food business. Her customers mainly are travelers at Kupaon street and also her neighbors. The money she earns is used to pay for the rent and also to help her to make end's meet.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Jl.Kupaon merupakan jalur yang sangat ramai karena merupakan jalur penghubung antara Denpasar dan daerah pariwisata seperti Sanur, Kuta dan Nusa Dua. Usaha warung yang digeluti Ibu Siti A. cukup lancar meskipun setiap hari dia harus bangun jam 04.00 pagi untuk belanja kebutuhan warung, Ibu Siti A. tetap semangat karena dibantu oleh suaminya, Adapun pembelinya adalah mereka yang lewat sekitar Jl.Kupaon dan juga tetangga sekitar. keuntungan yang didapat dari hasil usaha warung cukup untuk dipergunakan untuk membayar sewa kamar kost dan juga memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya.

loans.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Eith

texts.en: Mrs. Eith M., age 39, lives with her younger sister and works raising pigs at her house. She earns $3.5 a day. Her younger sister, Eith Me, age 30, owns a plot of farmland growing rice, making about $1 a day. These two sisters are requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase more pigs, food for the pigs, and fertilizers to put on the farmland. Moreover, any extra from the loan will be used to build a stable house.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs, food for the pigs, and fertilizers to put on the farmland

loans.name: Bou

texts.en: Bou S. is 50 years old and owns a small farm in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband have grown vegetables to sell in the market since 1980. They support themselves and their only child on a combined daily income of US $3. Their daughter also works at a local garment factory making US $50 per month. They want to invest in an additional plot of farmland on which to grow vegetables, which will bring them greater financial security.

loans.use: To buy farmland

loans.name: Fatma's Jiimarishe Group

texts.en:
Fatma S. is 35 years old and is divorced woman with 3 children, ages 12,8 and 2 years old. Fatma S. conduct a small business of making and selling chapatis, she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her chapati business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Fatma now hopes for a loan to buy more food items to make more chapatis for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Fatma Y.. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other member is responsible.

loans.use: To buy more food items to make chapatis

loans.name: Hafsa

texts.en:
Hafsa is 36 years old and is married with 4 children, ages 22,15,12 and 6 years old. Hafsa has a small business of selling sarongs that she started in 2005. Every day, she sells sarongs from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

In the past, Hafsa has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her sarong business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Yin

texts.en: Yin S. is a 38 year old rice farmer in the province of Kampong Cham. She earns less than US $1 per day farming. Her husband, Sek Chea, does a little bit better as an ice cream vendor in Siem Reap province earning US $5 per day. Of their three children, one is currently employed as a security guard making US $30 monthly. She wants to take out a loan to buy the necessary wood to fix her family home, which they can't afford on their regular income. They also hope to save some money to someday buy Sek Chea a motorbike, which he can use to make his business mobile.

loans.use: To renovate their home

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Im M. is 44 years of age and has been farming rice since 1998. She makes approximately US $1.60 per day. Her husband raises pigs earning US $1 daily. They have had seven children together, only one of whom is married. One of the older children helps the family by collecting juice from sugar palm trees to be refined into local wine. He adds US $2 per day to the family income. Two others help their father with the pigs. With her loan, Im M. hopes to buy more pigs for her husband to breed. She also wants to invest in a small grinding mill for food production that she can also rent out to her neighbors.

loans.use: To buy pigs and a grinding mill

loans.name: Mwanahamis's Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
Mwanahamis is 28 years old and is married with 2 children, ages 8 and 4 years old. Mwanahamis has a small business of making and selling chapatis that she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 9am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

In the past, Mwanahamis has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her chapati business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items such as flour, sugar, and oil for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Asha, Rehema and Nyeshi, who also have small businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more food items in order to make more chapatis

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: San

texts.en: San S. is 63 years old and runs a small grocery store out of her home in Kampong Cham province. Her husband, Man Chim, works with her in their store. They earn on average US $7.20 per day. Both of their children are grown up and living outside of the family home. She wants to buy groceries in bulk because she feels that expanding her inventory will attract more business as time goes on.

loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk

loans.name: Asha's Jitihad Group

texts.en:
Asha is 32 years old and is married. Asha started her small charcoal business in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm selling charcoal and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

In the past, Asha has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Zainabu, Mkasi, and Maulid, who also have small businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Saumu's Nyota Njema Group

texts.en:
Saumu is 25 years old and is married. Saumu conducts a small donut business that she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 7am to 8pm making and selling donuts at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Saumu now hopes for a loan to buy more food items to increase her production of donuts. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Mariam and Mwanaisha, who have small businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Suis

texts.id:
Mrs. Suis M. starts her electrical store in 2002. She sells various electrical supplies such as lamp, cable, electrical plug etc from major suppliers who deliver the goods to her store. She also sometimes buy her merchandise from another major/ bigger store at Denpasar. Her store is located at Kupaon street, one of the busiest street in Denpasar.

She uses the money she earn from this store to expand her business and also to improve her family's well being.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Ibu Suis M. mulai menjalankan usaha jual alat-alat listrik sejak tahun 2002. Alat-alat listrik yang dijual seperti lampu, kabel, stop kontak yang ia beli dari supplier yang mengantarnya langsung, dan juga ia membeli dari seputaran Kota Denpasar dan dijual di daerah Kupaon. Karena letaknya strategis dan berada ditempat yang padat penduduknya, usahanya begitu ramai dan banyak pengunjung atau pembeli yang ketokonya. Dari keuntungannya ia bisa pakai sebagai tambahan usaha dan untuk keperluan rumah tangganya.

loans.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ziada's Hatuyumbi Group

texts.en:
Ziada A. is 31 years old and is married. Ziada started her business of selling sarongs and bread in 2007. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Ziada has taken and repaid one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for another loan to buy more  sarongs and bread to sell. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have small businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutuA. guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more bread and sarongs to sell

loans.name: Sada's Safinia Group

texts.en:
Sada is a married woman. She started her business of making and selling chapatis in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

In the past, Sada has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items to make more chapatis for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in small business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more food items to make chapatis

loans.name: Eang

texts.en: Eang D., 50, lives with his wife and two children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. He grows rice and vegetables to earn around $5 a day. His wife, Sovann, is a local doctor. She makes $1 a day. Their children are students. This couple wants to borrow from Kiva to purchase more farmland to grow more rice in order to receive more output.

loans.use: To purchase wood to install in the house (repair work)

loans.name: Salama's Safinia Group

texts.en:
Salama is 41 years old and is married with 6 children, ages 5-29 years old. Salama started her business in 2008. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $33 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Zahra, who has business dealing in small business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutuA. guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Rodiyah

texts.id:
Rodiyah has been in the business of selling mixed rice for around 3.5 years by now. She buys her mixed rice's ingredients from Sanglah market which is located near by her house. She goes to the market at 04.00 am everyday and she starts to cook at 05.00 am. Her customers are travelers who pass by her food stall at Satelit Street and also her surrounding neighbors.

She wants to use the loan money to expand her food stall business.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Usaha jualan nasi campur sudah dimulai olehIbu Rodiyah sekitar 3,5 tahun yang lalu. Ibu Rodiyah biasanya belanja bahan-bahan kebutuhan warungnya di Pasar Sanglah yang jaraknya tidak jauh dari rumahnya. Ia berangkat pukul 04.00 ke pasar dan pukul 05.00 ia sudah mulai memasak. Para konsumennya adalah mereka yang lewat sekitar Jl. Satelit dan orang-orang yang kost disekitar wilayah itu. Pinjaman kali ini rencananya akan dipergunakan sebagai penunjang modal usahanya mengembangkan warung nasi campur..

loans.use: To add working capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Lipi

texts.en:
Lipi is 42 years old and is married with 3 children, ages 21,12, and 9 years old. Lipi started her small juice and chapati business in 2008. Every day, she makes and sell these items from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items to make more juice and chapatis. She is a member of a loan group, whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more food items to make juice and chapatis

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en: Sabina O. lives in Ilogbo, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a married woman with 8 children and she sells textbooks and greeting cards. Sabina acquired this skill in 1 month and has been in her business since 1988. At 46 years of age, she wants to diversify her business to sell office accessories, like staplers and perferators, in addition to her textbooks and greeting cards. She needs a loan of $600 to enable her to buy more textbooks and office accessories to see.  She says "thank you."

loans.use: To buy more books and office accessories.

loans.name: Mosi's Heri Yetu Group

texts.en:
Mosi is 38 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 18,12, and 8 years old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other people, ages 76 years old. Mosi has a small business that she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $33 from her sales.

In the past, Mosi has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who also have small businesses.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mgeni's Heri Yetu Group

texts.en:
Mgeni is 39 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 16,12,8 and 5 years old. Mgeni is a business woman. She started in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $23 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Nadra,Khadija and Bimkubwa, all of whom have small businesses.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Hidaya's Hatutaki Matatizo Group

texts.en:
Hidaya is 39 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 15 and 10 years old. Hidaya is a business woman. She started in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Hidaya has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Fatma, Chema and Mtumwa, who have small businesses.

loans.use: To buy more items for her busienss.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Hidaya's Hatutaki Matatizo Group

texts.en:
Hidaya is 39 years old and is married woman with 2 children, ages 15 and 10 years old. hidaya is a business woman, she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

In the past, Hidaya has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Fatma, Chema and Mtumwa, who have businesses dealing in small businesses.

loans.use: To buy more items for her busienss.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia U. sells clothes and tailoring materials.She has been in this business for the past 6 years. She lives in Iyanuera in Lagos State, Nigeria.She is 27 years of age with 2 children, and has being borrowing from LAPO microfinance for the past 2 years.

Felicia needs a loan of $875 to enable her buy more clothes and tailoring material in order to expand her business. She is thankful to Kiva for this opportunity. This can be seen from the broad smile in her face throughout our interview.

loans.use: To buy more cloths and tailoring materials.

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
