Christiana E. is a married woman. She is 25 years old. She sells provisions, drinks and cosmetics, and she has been in this business for the past 5 years. She hails from Igbede, Lagos State, Nigeria.

Christiana needs a loan of $600 to enable her buy more provisions, cosmetics and drinks to sell. With this loan, she said her business will be positioned for greater performance. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and cosmetics.

loans.name: Hadija's Nyota Njema Group

texts.en:
Hadiaj is 43 years old and is a married woman with 6 children, ages 8-29 years old. Hadija has a small business. She started in 2006. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

In the past, Hadija has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Mwandawa, who has a small business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Vero

texts.en: Vero L.’s business has of two categories: she sells fish and gently used clothing. At 44 years of age with 5 children, she still has enough energy to sell fish in the evening after returning from the market where she sells used clothes. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 4 years and hails from Ajamgbadi, Lagos State, Nigeria. She needs a loan of $600 to enable her buy more fish and used clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more dry fish and used clothes

loans.name: Mariam's Tusaidiane Group

texts.en:
Mariam, age 38, is married with four children, ages 17, 12, and 6 year-old twins. She has a charcoal-selling business which she started in 2005. She works from 7 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. daily, and makes a profit of about $55 a month from her sales.

In the past, Mariam took out a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy more charcoal to sell. She repaid it, and now hopes for a new loan which she will use for the same purpose. She will share this loan with her group, whose members run businesses in which they sell items such as drinks, fruits and vegetables, and provide tailoring services.

In the picture, Mariam is in yellow on the right.

loans.use: To help several small businesses expand

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Tujijenge Tanzania Ltd - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Bbogo Women's Group

texts.en:
Bbogo is a small village in Lugazi where the soil is very fertile. N. Dezi, the chairperson of Bbogo Women’s Group, has taken advantage of that fertility by raising bananas known locally as matooke, potatoes and maize on her family's land. She also prepares a local brew known as waragi for sale using a certain kind of banana that grows on her farm. She also buys these bananas from other farmers, since demand for the beverage is extremely high, especially among fishermen.

Dezi is 42 years old, married and has 10 children, six girls and four boys. She chairs a loan group that has been together for 10 years. All of the group's members agree that before loans were available, life was hard and if your business encountered problems, that was the end. Now, one can get a loan and invest in other businesses while growing your own and helping it through hard times. Because this is possible, local people can now send their children to school.

Dezi has applied for a new loan to expand her businesses by buying more bananas and a drum in which to make waragi, as well hire workers for her farm who can help her prepare to plant new crops. The other members of this group will use their portions of this loan to expand their own small businesses.

loans.use: To help several small businesses grow

loans.name: Yi

texts.en: Yi L. is 42 years old and lives in Siem Reap. She makes her living selling fish in the local market. Her business does relatively well, bringing in US $8 per day. Her husband works as a motor taxi driver based in front of a local hospital. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. The remaining four are all enrolled in school. She wants to expand her market-stand’s inventory by buying more expensive kinds of fish. She hopes this will make her business more competitive.

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Siti's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Siti is 45 years old and is a widow with 6 children, ages 12-20 years old. Siti is a business woman. She started in 1978. Every day, she works from 7am to 3pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $200 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have small businesses.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Sekinut

texts.en:
Sekinut A. is 35 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her business is not too common in her community where she lives; she sells plywood and packing case wood. She hails from Ajamgbadi, Lagos State, Nigeria and has been in business since 1998.

Sekinut has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years and she is requesting a loan of $875 to enable her buy more plywood and packing case wood to sell.

loans.use: To buy more of plywood and packing case wood

loans.name: Sudi's Tushikamane Group

texts.en:
Sudi, age 52, is married and has five children, ages 30, 25, 20, 18 and 16. He owns a stationary shop where he sells office supplies. He started this business in 2006, and works there from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily. Each month, the shop brings in about $380 in profit.

In the past, Sudi has taken out four loans to buy more stock for his shop. He paid these loans back, and now has applied for a new loan to open a small general store. He will share the loan with his group, whose members have businesses in which they sell chips, vegetables, beverages, food and other items.

In the picture, Sudi is standing in the back row, wearing a white shirt.

loans.use: To open a small general store and support other small businesses

loans.name: Asha's Sitaki Shari Group

texts.en:
Asha is 35 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 12-20 years old. Asha has a small business. She started in 2004. Every day, she works from 8am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Viwe, who has a small business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en: Mwanjuma is 47 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 25,24,23 and 20 years. Mwanajuma is a business woman. She started in 1998. Every day, she works from 7am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Folake

texts.en:
Folake Y. is a wholesale distributor of charcoal. She buys her charcoal from Ogun State Market. She makes the three-hour journey by car four times each month. She lives in Ajangbadi, Lagos State, Nigeria.

She acquired the skill of trading in 1½ years and has been in her business since 2001. She needs of a loan of $875 to buy more charcoal to sell.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Mosumola

texts.en: Mosumola L. sells notebooks, textbooks, and greeting cards in her bookshop not too far from Iyano – Ajangbandi community in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 48 years old with 4 children,  two of whom assist her in the shop. She acquired her skill in a year and has been in this business since 2003. She needs a loan of $875 to buy more books and textbooks to sell. She says "thank you!"

loans.use: To buy more notebooks & textbooks for sale.

loans.name: Rath

texts.en: Rath S. is 35 years old and makes her living selling vegetables from her home. She earns US $5 per day in this business. Her husband, Hen Saroeut, is a construction foreman for their local village earning US $3 per day. Together they have three young children. She wants to take out a loan so she can afford to fix her home as it is also her storefront. With any left over money she will purchase vegetables in bulk.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables and fix the house

loans.name: Tweeweeyo Women's Group

texts.en:
Barbara K. is the chairperson of Tweweeyo Women’s Group, which is located in the Lweru trading center. This group has been together for eight years. Kagoyais operates a beauty parlor in Lweru called the Nalongo Beauty Salon. It has operated successfully for eight years, and specializes in braiding, weaving and perming hair using weaves, braids and hair creams such as Ultra sheen, Venus and Movit that she gets in Lugazi Town.

Barbara is 37 years old and married with seven children, six of whom are in school. Her youngest child is still breastfeeding. Her husband works at a nearby business, and together they earn enough money to run their home and pay school fees for their children. She is thankful for the loans she has received in the past, and has now applied for a new loan through Kiva because she has heard other people talk favorably about it and believes it is a great opportunity for the group.

loans.use: To buy supplies for a beauty parlor and help several other small businesses

loans.name: Kulwa's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Kulwa M. is 58 years old, married and has two children, ages 21 and 19. He runs a furniture store which he opened six years ago. He works from 7:30 a.m to 6 p.m. daily, and makes a profit of about $424 a month.

In the past, Kulwa has taken out four loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase the stock of furniture he has to sell. He has applied for a new loan for the same purpose. Kulwa will share this loan with the members of his group, who sell items such as fruit and vegetables, and services such as carpentry, butchery and grooming.

In the photo, Kulwa is second from the left in the back row, wearing a white shirt.

loans.use: To help several small businesses expand

loans.name: Morm

texts.en: Morm N. is 28 years old. She works in a hotel in Siem Reap earning US $4 per day. Run Sophal, her husband (pictured here as she was unavailable), works as a motor taxi driver earning US $4 per day. They have two young children who are not yet old enough for school. She wants to build a well by their home so that she can run a small business pumping and selling water in her neighborhood.

loans.use: To dig a new well

loans.name: Jema

texts.en: Jema is a married woman with 2 children, ages 22 and 18 years old. Jema owns a small shop. She started in 2003. Every day, she works from 7am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $9 from her sales. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Khadija's Tupendane Group

texts.en:
Khadija is 44 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 24,17,13 and 9 years old. Khadija is a business woman. She started in 1993. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Fatma, who has a small business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina is 29 years old, married and has a three-year-old son. She runs a beauty salon and a shop. She started these businesses a year ago, and works from 6:30 a.m. to 9:30 p.m. managing them. The salon brings her a monthly profit of about $35, and the shop brings in about $280.

In the past, Paulina used a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy products for her beauty salon. Having paid this loan back successfully, she has applied a new loan to buy more products for her shop.

Paulina belongs to a loan group known as Umoja, whose 22 members ensure that the loans they take out will be repaid.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell from her shop

loans.name: Nsubuga's Group

texts.en:
Fred, Bena, Twaha and Zabina are members of the Tweweeyo Women’s Group, which is located in the Lweru trading center. They have applied for a group loan which will allow all of them to expand their businesses.

Fred sells yellow bananas to retailers and traders, and would like to buy more produce from farmers to sell to his clients. Bena sells local brews known as waragi and malwa, and would like to buy more sorghum and pots to make his work easier. Twaha deals in scrap, which he buys from the surrounding villages and sells to steel plants. He will use his loan to buy more materials to sell. Zabina has a six-year-old restaurant in Lweru, and needs a loan to buy more plates, spoons, saucepans and charcoal for cooking food.

loans.use: To help four small businesses expand

loans.name: Bikwao

texts.en:
Bikwao is 48 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 18,16 and 5 years old. Bikwao has a small business. She started in 1988. Every day, she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

In the past, Bikwao has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Sek Chan

texts.en: Sek Chan N. is 46 years old and lives in Siem Reap. She is a housewife while her husband works at a night club along with their eldest son. Her husband, Tuong Phan, earns US $6 per day. They want to secure their family's future by building a better home from which to possibly run a business in the future.

loans.use: To build a house

loans.name: Fatuma's Chimbuko Group

texts.en:
Fatuma, age 51, is married and has four children, ages 21, 19, 17 and 4 . For the past six years, she has made a living selling cosmetics and food. She works from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. daily, and makes a monthly profit of around $26.

In the past, Fatuma took out two loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to start her businesses. Now she has applied for a new loan to increase her capital and expand these businesses. Fatuma will share this loan with the Chimbuko group, which has 15 members. These members will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans. They run a variety of businesses which sell food, soft drinks and beer, oil, clothing, charcoal and other items.

In the picture, Fatuma is second from the left in a blue dress.

loans.use: To buy more food items and cosmetics

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
While visiting Victoria E. in Abulaka Community, Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria, we learned that she has been a widow for the past 10 years. Life has not been easy for her, but she manages her small business where she sells groceries, drinks and food. She has acquired her business skills over many years. She is now 51 years of age and has six children. She has been in business since 1988.

Victoria is requesting a loan of $875 to buy more groceries, food, and drinks to sell.

loans.use: To buy more Provisions, foodstuff & drinks for sale

loans.name: Abiodun

texts.en:
L. Abiodun sells notebooks and textbooks where she lives in Ajagbandi Community, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 33 years old, married, and has 2 children. She acquired the skill of trading in 4 years and has been operating this business since 1999.

She is requesting a loan of $1,025 to buy more textbooks and notebooks to sell. She is dedicated to her business.

loans.use: To buy more books and textbooks to sell

loans.name: Nghan

texts.en: Nghan S. is a 45 year old housewife living in Siem Reap. Her husband, Tan Sokhorn is 65 years old and is a local carpenter. He earns US $5 per day to support his wife and their two children. She wants to purchase a better set of carpentry tools for him to keep up with changing technology and protect their family's source of income.

loans.use: To buy better tools

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en: Chhorn S. is 28 years old and lives in Siem Reap province. She sells souvenirs to tourists by the famous Angkor temples around which her city has grown. She earns US $5 per day through her business. Her husband is a musician who runs a small shop selling traditional Cambodian instruments to tourists. They have two children who are not old enough to be in school. She wants to expand her inventory by ordering more souvenir products to meet the growing customer demand.

loans.use: To buy souvenirs for resale

loans.name: Maarufu's Ujamaa Group

texts.en:
M. M. is 32 years old, married and has two children, who are 10 and 3 years old. For the past six years, he has made a living selling secondhand clothing. He works from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily, and is able to make a monthly profit of about $254.

M. has applied for a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase the stock of clothing he has for sale. He will share this loan with his group members, and they will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

In the picture, M. is in the back row, second from the left.

loans.use: To buy more secondhand clothing to sell

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
The beautiful color display in Juliet O.’s shop makes her shop stand out from other shops in the locality. Her wares range from clothes, to handbags and jewelry. Juliet is a single woman and she is 29 years of age. Her aim is to improve her business, which will, in turn, increase her profit. She lives in Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria and has been in business since 1999.

Juliet needs a loan of $875 to buy more shoes, clothes and bags to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more clothes, bags and shoes

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en:
Mrs Toyin A. is a struggling woman who lives in Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. At 39 years of age with 4 children, she is the breadwinner of her family. She is trying her best to sell her frozen foods (turkey, chicken and fish) with just a deep freezer in the center of a local market in her community.

She acquired the skill of trading in 2 years, and has been in her business since 1993. Toyin is requesting a loan of $875 to buy a deep freezer and more frozen food so that she can increase the prosperity of her business.

loans.use: To buy more frozen food (chicken,turkey and fish)

loans.name: Salamotu

texts.en: Mrs. Salamotu M. has been a faithful client of LAPO Microfinance for the past 4 years. She is 36 years old and has 3 children. She sells groceries in cartons (wholesale). She hails from Ajambgadi, Lagos State, Nigeria and has being in business since 1999. She needs a loan of $875 to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.use: To buy more provision for sale.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy O. lives in Shibiri, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells shoes, clothes and bags, a skill that she acquired in a year. She has been in business since 2005. Joy is 32 years old, married, and has 4 children. She is determined to support her husband, who earns a meager salary, in improving the prosperity of the family.

She is asking for a loan of $875 to buy more shoes, clothes and bags. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more shoes, clothes and bags for sale.

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en:
Mr. Oeun M. and his wife have been married since 1979. They have five children; one son and four daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home.  The other three children work in a garment factory. The family lives along the Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mr. Oeun runs business in water supply distribution in the village. He has been doing this business for thirteen years. His wife has been a silk weaver for two years. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who then sells the them in Phnom Penh.  

He is requesting a loan in the amount of $800 to purchase a water pipeline and water pumping machine to run a business in water supply distribution.

loans.use: to purchase a water pipeline and water pumping machine to run a business in water supply distribution

loans.name: Sreymom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreymom D. and her husband married in 1997. They have no children. They live on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sreymom has been a weaver since 1990. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middle man in the village who will then sell them in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a policeman who operates a motor taxi in his spare time.

She is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase materials for weaving silk.

loans.use: to purchase materials to weave silk

loans.name: Yat

texts.en:
Mrs. Yat O. is a widow with eight children; one son and seven daughters. One of her children is married and lives outside the family home. Four of her children work in a garment factory, two weave silk at home and the youngest one studies at university. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers frO. PhnO. Penh.

Mrs. Yat has been a weaver since 1979. It’s a skill she learned frO. her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who then sells them in PhnO. Penh. 

She is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase material for weaving silk and pay school fees for her son.

loans.use: to purchase materials to weave silk and pay school fees for her son

loans.name: Beauty

texts.en: Mrs. Beauty A. sells groceries in Ilogbo Community, not too far from Ajamgbadi in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 32 years of age, married, and has 2 children. She acquired the skill of trading many years ago and has been in business since 2004. Beauty needs a loan of $600 to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Bridget U. is a typical business woman. She sells bread in Ireke Community, Lagos State, Nigeria. She was botn there and lives there even now. Bridget acquired her business skills many years ago and has been in this business since1988. At 53 years of age, with 8 children, she still has the energy needed for business. According to her, selling bread is the only skill she has acquired and, she treasures it. She is requesting a loan of $700 to buy more bread to sell.

loans.use: To buy more bread to sell

loans.name: Ahazi's Tarangire Group

texts.en:
Ahazi, age 64, is married and has 11 children. He started a furniture business in 1978, and works there from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily. From this business, he makes about $480 a month.

In the past, Ahazi used a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to expand his business. Having successfully paid back this loan, he has applied for a new one to continue this expansion. He will share this loan with his group, whose members are in the chicken- and charcoal-selling businesses.

loans.use: To buy more stock for his furniture business

loans.name: Ngot

texts.en:
Mrs. Ngot V. is a widow with four children; three sons and one daughter. Two of her children are married and live outside the family home. Of her other two children, one weaves silk at home and the youngest one is a construction worker. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Ngot has been a weaver for forty one years. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who will sell them in Phnom Penh. 

She is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase materials for weaving silk.

loans.use: To purchase materials for weaving silk

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhem S. is a widow with three children; two sons and one daughter. Two of her sons are married and live outside the family house.  Her daughter is in school. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Nhem has been a weaver for thirty five years. It’s a skill she learned from her parents. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who will sell them in Phnom Penh. 

She is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase materials for weaving silk.

loans.use: to purchase materials for weaving silk

loans.name: Chinda

texts.en:
Mrs. Chinda Chok and her husband married in 2002. They have two sons. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Chinda has been a silk weaver for fifteen years. It’s a skill she learned from her relative. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who will then sell it in Phnom Penh. 

Her husband works in a garment factory in Phnom Penh. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase a motorbike for her husband for work purposes.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for her husband for work purposes

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria O. sells food in a local market in her community. She hails from Volk, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 36 years of age, married, and has 4 children. She has been in business since 2006. She needs a loan of $450 to buy more food to sell. She said this will help her to serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell

loans.name: Olaide

texts.en: Mrs. Olaide Shorinola hails from Ikundo, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sell groceries in her area. Although she did not undergo any training for her business, she is vocal and business-oriented. She is 45 years of age with 4 children and has been in business since 2005. Olaide needs a loan of $875 to to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Velida

texts.en: Velida was born in 1980 and she is married. Her husband has a full time job and his monthly income is 900,00KM. They have two children. Velida wants to use this loan of 800,00KM ($650 USD) to buy food for her livestock in order to improve her business. She breeds cows and sells milk products.

loans.use: For buying food for livestock.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Anitha's Muungano Middle Group

texts.en:
Anitha is 24 years old and is married woman with a 6-year-old child. Anitha owns a small grocery store, which she started in 2005. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Mariam and Mwanahamisi, who have small businesses.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Groupment Dagan

texts.en:
Groupement Dagan is a business created by 5 women in Adéta, Togo, a medium-sized town located aproximately 150 kilometers from the capital. The group is composed of Philomene A., the manager, a 38-year-old married woman; Louise A., a 26-year-old married woman; her sister Mofemo A., a 28-year-old married woman; Abra T., a 37-year-old married woman; and Marie M., a 31-year-old woman who is not yet married.

This close-knit group of family and friends sell a variety of prepared food in the central market of Adéta in order to earn a living and provide for their respective families. With this loan, the women of Group Dagan hope to restock their supply of yams, grains, vegetables various animals for the preparation of dishes to sell in the market. Their food is very popular and they hope that this loan will help them to satisfy the demands of their customers, enlarge their clientele and improve the quality of all of their lives.

loans.use: To restock their supply of yams, grains, vegetables and various animals for the preparation of food

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FECECAV - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Zehra

texts.en: Zehra was born in 1959 and she is married. Her husband has a private job and his monthly income is 950,00KM. They have 2 children. Zehra wants to use this loan of 700,00KM ($575 USD) to buy poultry, in order to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: For buying poultry.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Tabia

texts.en: Tabia is 29 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 8 and 2 years old. Tabi  owns a small grocery store, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 9am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $75 from her sales. She now hopes for a loan to buy more  items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food for her business.

loans.name: Mirela

texts.en:
Mirela was born in Čivčije and she is married. Her husband has a full time job and his monthly salary is 500,00KM. Mirela has two children, 7 and 4 years old. Their additional income is their children's allowance.

Mirela wants to use this loan of 600,00KM ($500 USD) to buy a motorized saw in order to expand her business. Her husband does the felling and he can earn additional money for their household.

loans.use: To buy a power saw

loans.name: Mary's Bombo North Group

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman with 6 children. Mary owns a small grocery store, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Fatuma and Veronica, who sell cloth.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Marian

texts.en:
Marian S. lives in Era Community, not too far from Volk, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells rubber sandals and has been in business since 1998. Marian is 38 years of age, married, and has 4 children. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for 2 years.

She needs a loan of $875 to buy more shoes to sell. She said the loan will help her to improve her business and make more profit. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more shoe for sale

loans.name: Mina

texts.en:
Mina was born in 1966 and she lives with her husband and two children in Klokotnica, a suburb of the town of Doboj. Her husband is a demobilized soldier and he is unemployed. Mina works in a factory as a tyipist. Her husband gets an additional salary of 150 KM per month as a demobilized soldier. One of her sons attends university and the other one attends secondary school.

This is her first loan in the amount of 600 KM. Mina intends to use it to buy food for her livestock. Her wish is to expand her livestock business in order to increase her monthly income.

loans.use: For buying food for the livestock.

loans.name: Judith's Muungano South Group

texts.en:
Judith is 29 years old and is a single woman. Judith is a tailor. She started in 1999. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Jetsina, who also has a tailoring business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en: Saumu is 27 years old and is a single woman. Saumu owns a small shop that she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 7am to 9pm at her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more  items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Zilka

texts.en: Zilka was born in 1968 and she is married. Her husband is a locksmith and his monthly salary is KM 400, 00. They have 3 children, ages 11, 12 and 18. Zilka wants to use this loan for 600,00KM to buy a calf to expand her business as well as her income.

loans.use: To buy a calf

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin O. hails from ikundo, Lagos State, Nigeria. She and her elder sister combined their finances to buy a machine that they both to produce nylon. She has been in this business since 1993 and she acquired the skill after one year. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years. She is soliciting a loan of $875 to buy more material for nylon production.

loans.use: To buy more materials for nylon production

loans.name: Almira

texts.en: Almira was born in 1978 and she is not married. She lives alone in a small place called Orahovica. She earns 300,00KM monthly from agriculture work. In the period when she is not employed, Almira sells cosmetics. She wants to use this loan for 1000, 00KM for growing potatoes to enlarge her business and earn additional income.

loans.use: For growing potatoes.

loans.name: Fadila

texts.en:
Fadila was born in 1957 and she is married. Her husband is a pensioner and he also does agriculture work. He can earn about 400 KM monthly. His monthly pension is 280 KM. They have two children, 22 and 30 years old.

This is her first loan of 1000 KM. Fadila will use it to expand her barn. She hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: For expanding the barn.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en: Benedicta E. lives in Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells weave-ons and hair-lengthening attachments in her area. She acquired the skill after 1 year and has been in business since 2004. She is 35 years of age and has 3 children. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy more hair attachments and weave-ons to sell.

loans.use: To buy hair attachments for her salon.

loans.name: Tima

texts.en:
Tima was born in 1958 and she is married. She has one daughter, who is 15 years old. Her husband is a seasonal worker who works with a tractor. His monthly salary is KM 350, 00. When her husband is not employed, he buys vegetables that they grow. Their additional income is a pension from her father-in-law of KM 280, 00.

Tima wants to use this loan for 1000, 00KM to buy cattle to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy cattle.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Refija

texts.en:
Refija was born in 1951, and she lives in Gračanica. She is married and has 3 daughters, ages 33, 34 and 36. Her husband has a full time job at the Eurodom construction firm and his monthly salary is KM 900,00. 

Refija wants to use this loan for 1000, 00 KM to buy a calf. Her wish is to expand her business and sign a contract with a dairy.

loans.use: For buying a calf.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Mrs. Christiana M. sells cooked food and drinks in Afro Media, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 42 years old, married, and has 3 kids. Christiana acquired the skill of trading in 3 years and has been in business since 1993. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to enable her buy more drinks and food to sell.

loans.use: To buy more food and drink to sell.

loans.name: Munevera

texts.en:
Munevera is a 31-year-old woman from Babići, a small village near the town Gračanica. She is married and she has two children, ages 7 and 10 years old, who go to primary school.

This is her third loan from MCO WWI (Women for Women International). The first loan was for 5 000 KM, the second loan was for 1000 KM and this loan is for 500 KM. Munevera is taking this loan to buy food for her livestock. Her wish is to expand her livestock business.

loans.use: To buy food for livestock.

loans.name: Latifa

texts.fr:
Born on December 31, 1970, in Tchaoudjo in Togo, Ms. Latifa A. is married and the mother of three. She is an energetic woman and professionally manages her fashion boutique "Intellect Couture" that she created in 1990. She still includes the sale of pagnes (colorful print fabrics) and sewing-related items in her primary business. The first loan of 300,000 francs CFA that she obtained enabled her to acquire an extra sewing machine and an overcasting (stitching) machine. After having repaid her first loan without incident, she is requesting at present a loan of 400,000 francs CFA to buy 25 bolts of pagnes, 10 rolls of cloth, and a dozen rolls of decorative lace.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Née le 31 décembre 1970 à Tchaoudjo au Togo, Madame A. Latifa est mariée et mère de trois (3) enfants. Elle est une femme dynamique et gère avec professionnalisme son atelier de couture « INTELLECT COUTURE » qu’elle a crée depuis 1990. Elle associe toujours la vente de pagne et des produits de mercerie à son activité principale. Le premier crédit qu’elle a obtenu d’un montant de 300.000FCFA lui a permis d’acquérir une machine à coudre supplémentaire et une machine de surfilage. Après un bon remboursement de son premier crédit, Madame A. Latifa sollicite à présent un crédit de 400.000 FCFA pour acheter vingt cinq (25) pièces de pagne, dix huit (18) rouleaux de tissus et douze (12) rouleaux de guipures.

loans.use: To buy and sell pagnes

loans.name: Kouessoua

texts.fr:
Miss Kouessoua K. was born on June 5, 1966 in Niamey, Niger. She is single and is the breadwinner for four persons. Her primary business activity is the sale of lengths of African print cloth in the big open-air market in Lomé. She has been in this business for more than 10 years.

In view of Miss Kouessoua K.'s experience in this line of work, she was able to obtain her first loan of US$ 1200 which she reimbursed in a timely fashion. Her large assortment of various African prints works to attract her clientele, and she is thus able to meet her needs with the income from her business.

This second loan of US$ 1200 wil allow her to purchase 50 lengths of "fanci"-style print cloth for her inventory.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Mademoiselle K. Kouessoua est née le 5 juin 1966 à Niamey au Niger. Elle est célibataire avec quatre (04) personnes à charge. Elle a pour activité principale le commerce de pagne au grand marché de Lomé. Elle exerce cette activité depuis plus de dix (10) ans.

Avec l’expérience que Mademoiselle K. Kouessoua a dans l’exercice de cette activité, elle avait obtenu un premier crédit d’un montant de 500.000 FCFA et a bien remboursé. Son stock considérable de pagne constitue pour elle un moyen d’attraction des clients. Ainsi Le revenu de son commerce lui permet de faire face à ses besoins.

Le renouvellement de son crédit d’un montant de 500.000 FCFA lui permettra d’acheter cinquante (50) pièces de pagne de type fanci.

loans.use:
Purchase of "fanci"-style African print cloth for re-sale

Achat de pagne de type fanci destiné à la vente

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella F.’s business is growing every day. This can be seen by the rapid increase in her daily sales. She used to fry yams and potatoes, but for the past two years she has been selling cooked food, because LAPO Microfinance has come to her financial aid.

She is 43 years old, married, and has 4 children. She comes from Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. Stella is requesting a loan of $450 to buy more yams, potatoes, and food to sell. She said this will help her to serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy more yams, potatoes, and food item

loans.name: Fadila

texts.en:
Fadila is a 54-year-old woman from the town of Gračanica. She is divorced and she has one child, who is 25 years old. She has a pension in the amount of 280 KM. 

This is her first loan and its is for 1000 KM. Fadila intends to use this loan to buy chickens. She wishes to expand the business that she started with chickens.

loans.use: To buy chicken.

loans.name: Zoraida

texts.en: Zoraida was born in 1953 and she is married. Her husband has a full-time job and his monthly income is KM 1500, 00. This is the first time they have taken a loan. The amount of the current loan is KM 1200, 00. Zoraida wants to use it to buy chicken and turkey, in order to improve her business and allow her to sell poultry at the market.

loans.use: For buying chicken and turkey.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mirjana

texts.en:
Mirjana was born in 1986 and she is not married. Her additional monthly income is KM 300, 00.

Her previous loan was for 1200, 00KM. Mirjana wants to use the current loan of KM 1200, 00 to buy additional equipment for her computer. She wants to improve her writing of graduation and seminar papers and to expand her bookkeeping and other computer-related work.

loans.use: For buying additional equipment for the computer.

loans.name: Aleksandra

texts.en: Aleksandra was  born in 1984  and she  is not  married.  She lives with her family in East Sarajevo. She is a student and she receives a monthly stipend of 100 KM. This is her first loan, and it is for 1200 KM. Aleksandra will use it to buy additional clothes for her boutique where she works. She wishes to expand the business and open her own boutique because she wants to be independent.

loans.use: To buy clothes for the boutique.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Jehova Provee Group

texts.en:
Josefina lives in S. Pedro D. Macoris with her husband and six children (ages: 21,16,15,12, 9, 4). Currently she is running a small salon, and selling both sheets and curtains to families in her community or other passers-by. She wants to use this loan to buy materials to make sheets and curtains for her little shop. Josefina’s dream for the future is to own her own cafeteria, where she can prepare and sell food to people for breakfast and lunch. She said that her main struggle right now is saving up enough money to start the cafeteria, but she believes that it will happen soon.

This is the first loan that these ten people of Jehova Provee are applying for, and they are excited to see it go to good use in their various business and homes. We all want to extend our thanks to Kiva for continually supporting the people of the Dominican Republic. God bless!

loans.use: To buy material for sheets and curtains.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence D.’s business is booming, because she has all it takes to satisfy her customers, ranging from provisions, drinks and food. She acquired the skill of trading in 2 years and has been in the business since 1993. She is 55 years old, married, and has 2 children. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 4 years.

Florence needs a loan of $450 to buy a generator so that she can cool all of her drinks in case there is a power failure, that is, when the Power Holding Company of Nigeria (PHCN) fails to supply electricity. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy a generator

loans.name: Sanja

texts.en:
Sanja is a 22-year-old woman from East Sarajevo. She is not married and she lives with her parents.

Sanja will use this loan for 1000 KM for purchase on wholesale trade more plastic dishes, vases and other plastic items for household that she resells. She has a shop where she is retailing these items. Her wish is to expand the business in order to employ more people and to become a self-employed woman.

loans.use: For purchase more material.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Akouvi Délali

texts.fr:
Born on June 24, 1970 in Woamé (a town situated 135 kilometers from Lomé), Mrs. Akouvi Délali, wife of A. E. S., has four children who are all enrolled in school. After having been in the cereals business around 1994, she began to sell lengths of African print cloth and boubous (traditional African clothing) in 2005 in the Hédzranawoé market in Lomé. Ever since she took up this business venture, she has been able to help her husband pay their children's school fees.

The loan that she is presently requesting, her first, will permit her to purchase 10 lengths of GTP African print cloth (a mid-quality brand) so that she can diversify her inventory of various prints.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Née le 24 juin 1970 à Woamé (localité située à 135 Km de Lomé), Madame A. Epouse S. Akouvi Délali a quatre (4) enfants qui fréquentent tous. Après avoir exercé le commerce de vente de céréales dans les années 94, elle a débuté le commerce de pagne et de boubou en 2005 dans le marché de Hédzranawoé à Lomé. Depuis qu’elle a démarré cette activité, elle a toujours aidé son mari dans les dépenses scolaires de leurs enfants.

Le premier crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter dix (10) pièces de pagne de type GTP (qualité intermédiaire de pagne) en vue de diversifier les variétés de pagne dans son stock.

loans.use:
Purchase of GTP African prints, a good quality type of cloth

Achat de pagne GTP, un type de pagne de bonne qualité

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr:
Mrs. E. Mariama was born on January 23, 1986 in Lomé. She is a travelling saleswoman and re-sells fabric and shoes in the district of Nukafu in Lomé. On average, she walks up to twelve (12) kilometers per day. With this first credit in the amount of $1,200, she plans to start a jewelery business.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Translator

Madame E. Mariama est née le 23 janvier 1986 à Lomé. Elle est revendeuse ambulante de pagne et de chaussures dans le quartier de Nukafu à Lomé. Elle parcourt à pieds en moyenne une distance de douze (12) kilomètres par jour. Avec le premier crédit qu’elle sollicite d’un montant de 500.000 FCFA, elle envisage débuter le commerce de bijoux.

loans.use: Starting a jewelery business

loans.name: Confort

texts.en:
Confort A. is a trader who deals in jewels. She is married and has 5 dependents. Confort is a very hard-working woman who is helping her husband with the family’s expenses. She wishes to increase sales to increase her income.

She is asking for $325 as additional capital to buy more jewels for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more jewels for sale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 24, 2008)
Correction due to overpayment for business 43921

loans.name: Kossi Lolo

texts.fr:
Mr D. Kossi Lolo was born on June 30, 1972 in Lomé. He is married and is a father of two (2) children. In 2003, he started a copying/office supplies business in the district of Agoè, where he also sells stationery for schools. In 2007, due to the success of his business, he created a second shop in the district of Adidoadé in Lomé. He is asking for his first credit in the amount of $725, which will make it possible for him to buy a new photocopier, a box of toner and paper supplies. With this new purchase, he will be able to better answer the needs of his customers.

Translated by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Translator

Monsieur D. Kossi Lolo est né le 30 juin 1972 à Lomé. Il est marié et père de deux (2) enfants. Il a crée en 2003 un centre de traitement de texte, de photocopie et de vente des fournitures scolaires dans le quartier d’Agoè. En 2007 compte tenue de l’évolution de son activité, il a crée un second centre dans le quartier Adidoadé toujours Lomé. Le premier crédit d’un montant de 300.000 FCFA qu’il sollicite lui permettra d’acquérir une nouvelle photocopieuse, une boîte d’encre et un paquet de rame. Ainsi avec cette nouvelle acquisition, il pourra bien répondre à la demande de ses clients.

loans.use: Purchase of photocopiers and toners for copying/office supplies business

loans.name: Bakogma

texts.fr:
Mrs. Bakogma B. was born on July 23, 1973 in Lomé. She is married and has six children who are all enrolled in school. She has been managing to make ends meet since 2001 by selling used clothing. Her sources of income are so limited that she is not even able to pay rent. She has built herself a shelter out of sheet metal in the Agbalépédo neighborhood where she and her children live.

This first loan in the amount of US$ 250 will allow her to purchase a bale of used clothes so that she can improve her inventory.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Madame B. Bakogma est née le 23 juillet 1973 à Lomé. Elle est mariée et a six (6) enfants qui fréquentent tous. Elle se débrouille à travers la vente de friperies depuis 2001. Ses sources de revenus sont tellement limitées qu’elle n’arrive même pas à supporter les loyers ; Alors elle a fait un enclos avec des tôles au bord des rails dans le quartier d’Agbalépédo où elle réside avec ses enfants.

Le premier crédit d’un montant de 100.000 FCFA qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter un ballot de friperie afin d’améliorer son stock.

loans.use:
Purchase of a bale of used clothing

Achat d'un ballot de friperies

loans.name: Kossiwa

texts.fr:
Mrs A. Kossiwa was born on January 1, 1970 in Lomé. She is married and a mother of three children. She is a seamstress and opened a workshop in the district of Agoè where she also sells fabrics and other sewing materials. Currently, her supply of fabrics has been exhausted and she should like to replenish it. To this end, she is asking for a first credit of $300 to buy two cartons of sewing thread, twenty four rolls of poplin, ten rolls of lace and some zippers.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Translator

Madame A. Kossiwa est née le 1er janvier 1970 à Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère de trois (3) enfants. Elle a ouvert son atelier de couture et de vente des produits de mercerie dans le quartier d’Agoè. Actuellement son stock de mercerie est épuisé et elle désire faire un approvisionnement. A cet effet, elle sollicite un premier crédit de 300.000FCFA pour acheter deux (2) cartons de fil à coudre, vingt quatre (24) rouleaux de popelines, dix (10) rouleaux de guipures et quelques fermetures.

loans.use: Purchase of sewing thread and poplins

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr:
Born in 1965 in Tabligbo in the Yoto Prefecture, Mrs. Abra K. is married and the mother of four children. Her principle business venture is stocking and re-selling beans. She also buys goats and sells them to restaurant owners in Lomé. Moreover, she has a well at her home so that she can sell drinking water to other families in her neighborhood. In eight plastic tanks of 1000 liters each, she is presently stockpiling beans that she plans to sell in the month of June.

So as not to infringe on her venture, Mrs. Abra K. is requesting her first loan in the amount of US$ 725 to purchase 35 goats for re-sale.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Née en 1965 à Tabligbo dans la préfecture de Yoto, Madame K. Abra est mariée et mère de quatre (4) enfants. Elle a pour activité principale le stockage et la vente du haricot. Elle achète et revend également les chèvres aux restaurateurs de Lomé. Elle a aussi fait un forage à la maison pour vendre de l’eau potable aux ménages de son quartier. Actuellement elle a fait de stock du haricot dans huit (8) polytanks de 1000litres de contenance qui sont destinés à la vente dans le mois de juin.

Pour ne pas enfreindre à son activité, Madame K. Abra sollicite un premier crédit de 300.000 FCFA pour continuer son commerce par l’achat de trente cinq (35) chèvres.

loans.use:
Purchase of 35 goats for re-sale

Achat de 35 chèvres destinées à la vente

loans.name: Piyalo

texts.fr:
Mrs Y. Piyalo was born on March 14, 1964 in Kouméya in the KOZAH region in Togo. She is married and a mother of three children. She prepares and sells a type of local drink in Lomé, made from millet and water. This is a local drink which is drunk from a special pot and is popular with many people. Mrs Y. Piyalo would like to increase her stock of millet in order to avoid shortages. Thus, with this first request, she is asking for a loan of $725 the purchase of twelve bags of millet.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Translator

Madame Y. Piyalo est née le 14 mars 1964 à Kouméya dans la préfecture de la KOZAH au Togo. Elle est mariée et mère de trois (3) enfants. Elle a pour activité principale, la préparation et la vente de la boisson locale à Lomé. Cette boisson se prépare à base du mil et de l’eau. C’est une boisson locale qui se boit à l’aide d’une calebasse et est appréciée par beaucoup de personnes. Madame Y. Piyalo désire augmenter son stock de mil afin d’éviter des ruptures. Ainsi, pour son premier crédit, elle sollicite 300.000 FCFA pour l’achat de douze (12) sacs de mil.

loans.use: Purchase of 12 bags of millet

loans.name: Delicias 3 Group

texts.es:
Josefina Flavia is 58 years old, the mother of 6 children and has worked preparing typical regional food-tamales- for ten years now, every weekend afternoon. With her loan, she will purchase corn, firewood or coal, because these are the primary ingredients needed to make tamales. She belongs to the group Delicias 3 (delights) along with Mrs. Francisca Rutila (who sells typical regional food), Josefa (who sells popcorn and fritters made from flour called Chicharrines), Susana Victoria (who sells sweets), Ana Maria (who sells fish) and Ylda de Jesus (who sells fruits and vegetables).

Translated from Spanish to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

JOSEFINA FLAVIA TIENE 58 AÑOS, TUVO SEIS HIJOS, APROXIMADAMENTE POR DIEZ AÑOS SE HA DEDICADO A PREPARAR UN PLATILLO TIPICO DE LA REGION LLAMADO TAMALES QUE VENDE TODOS LOS FINES DE SEMANA POR LAS TARDES. CON SU PRESTAMO INVERTIRA EN LA COMPRA DE MAIZ, LEÑA O CARBON AL POR MAYOR YA QUE ES LA MATERIA PRIMA PARA ELABORAR LOS TAMALES. PERTENECE AL GRUPO SOLIDARIO LLAMADO DELICIAS 3 JUNTO CON DOÑA FRANCISCA RUTILA (VENTA DE COMIDA TIPICA DE LA REGION), JOSEFA (VENTA DE PALOMITAS Y DE FRITURAS DE HARINA LLAMADO CHICHARRINES), SUSANA VICTORIA (VENTA DE DULCES), ANA MARIA (VENTA DE PESCADO) E YLDA DE JESUS (VENTA DE FRUTAS Y VERDURAS).

loans.use: To purchase corn, coal or firewood, and condiments.

loans.name: Akossiwa Grâce

texts.fr:
Born in 1973 in Tsévié, a town situated 35 kilometers from Lomé, Mrs. Akossiwa Grâce T. is married and the mother of three children. She lives with her husband Komi Gavi, who is an auto mechanic. Her principal business is selling cereals. She began in this line of work in 1994 and knows all the ins and outs of her trade.

This first loan of US$ 725 that she is requesting will allow her to purchase nine bags of manioc flour and four bags of "cossette" (made from yams). With this inventory, she believes she will be able to increase her sales and help her husband who has not got a regular income.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Née en 1973 à Tsévié localité située à 35 km de Lomé, Madame T. Akossiwa Grâce est mariée et mère de trois (3) enfants. Elle vit avec son mari GAVI Komi qui est un mécanicien à quatre roues. Elle a pour activité principale le commerce de céréales. Elle a démarré cette activité depuis 1994 et maîtrise tous les contours de son commerce.

Le premier crédit qu’elle sollicite d’une valeur de 300.000 FCFA lui permettra d’acheter neufs (9) sacs de farine de manioc et quatre (4) sacs de cossette. Avec le stock, elle pense augmenter ses recettes et aider son mari qui a un revenu irrégulier.

loans.use:
purchase of 9 bags of cereals

Achat de 9 sacs de céréales

loans.name: Armonia 4 Group

texts.es:
Eneida Bonifacia has been selling clothing for two years along with gift items. She purchases her merchandise in Mexico City, which is ten hours away from her home. She travels there every 15 days, or once a month, depending on her sales. She works from home and part of the gift items she sells she makes with creativity, using materials like foam, thread, felt, cloths etc. She is 29 years old, the mother of three and belongs to the group called Armonia 4 (Harmony) along with: Rosario (who sells shoes), Evelia Roselva (who sells cakes), Olga Octavia (who raises chickens and pigs), Ana Isabel (who sells ice) and Frine Dessire (who sells silver jewelry).

Translated from Spanish to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

ENEIDA BONIFACIA SE DEDICA DESDE HACE DOS AÑOS A LA VENTA DE ROPA Y ARTICULOS DE REGALO. SU MERCANCIA LO COMPRA EN LA CIUDAD DE MEXICO LOCALIZADO A DIEZ HORAS, ELLA VIAJA CADA QUINCE DIAS O CADA MES DEPENDIENDO CUANTO HA VENDIDO DURANTE ESE TIEMPO. SU NEGOCIO LO TIENE INSTALADO EN SU CASA, PARTE DE LOS REGALOS QUE VENDE LOS ELABORA CON CREATIVIDAD UTILIZANDO MATERIAL DE FOMI, HILOS, FIELTRO, TELAS, ETC. ELLA TIENE 29 AÑOS, TRES HIJOS Y PERTENECE AL GRUPO SOLIDARIO LLAMADO ARMONIA 4 JUNTO CON: ROSARIO (VENTA DE ZAPATOS), EVELIA ROSELVA (VENTA DE PASTELITOS), OLGA OCTAVIA (CRIANZA DE POLLOS Y PUERCOS), ANA ISABEL (VENTA DE PALETAS DE HIELO) Y FRINE DESSIRE (VENTA DE JOYERIA DE PLATA).

loans.use: To purchase clothing and gift items.

loans.name: Mazama-Esso

texts.fr:
Mr. Mazama-Esso A. was born in 1973 in Adjengré, in the Sotouboua Prefecture in Togo. He is married and the father of two children. He is employed in the University Hospitality Center on the Lomé campus. In 2007 he opened a bar that he calls "Bar Sun 7" in Agoè. He manages the bar himself on weekends and holidays. On workdays, the bar is run by a manager he has employed and pays monthly. The bar is so successful that he is not able to satisfy all his customers' demands with the means at his disposition.

For this reason, Mr. Mazama-Esso A. is requesting his first loan in the amount of US$ 1200 so that he can add to his inventory by purchasing 85 cases of beer.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Monsieur A. Mazama-Esso est né en 1973 à Adjengré dans la préfecture de Sotouboua au Togo. Il est marié et père de deux (2) enfants. Il est employé de bureau au Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Campus à Lomé. En 2007, il a crée un bar qu’il nomme « BAR SUN 7 » à Agoè. Il gère ce bar seulement les week-end et les jours fériés. Le bar est géré les jours ouvrables par un gérant qu’il a engagé et a qui il paie à la fin du mois. L’affluence qui règne dans le bar fait en sorte qu’il n’arrive plus à satisfaire toutes les demandes de ses clients ; et avec ses moyens, seul il ne peut pas faire face à ses demandes.

A cet effet, Monsieur A. Mazama-Esso sollicite un premier crédit d’un montant de 500.000 FCFA pour faire l’approvisionnement par l’achat de quatre vingt cinq (85) casiers de bière.

loans.use:
Purchase of 85 cases of beer

Achat de 85 casiers de bière

loans.name: Edwin

texts.es:
Edwin is a humble farmer in the central area of Peru, who dedicates himself to growing vegetables thanks to his ancestral heritage and he is very successful with the help of his loving wife. The family’s annual source of income is the selling of his vegetable harvest and now thanks to his wife’s initiatives who also raises and sells small animals. This year he hopes to sell his products without middlemen in order to obtain greater profits and begin to gain experience in order to be able to help his neighbors do the same, for the benefit of hundreds of families in his beloved city. So that this project has a good end he is asking for your help in acquiring a greater quantity of manure and fertilizers that will optimize the size and nutriciousness of his crops.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

Edwin, es un humilde agricultor de la zona central de Perú, se dedica a la siembra de vegetales gracias a su herencia ancestral con mucho éxito y con la ayuda de su amada esposa. Su principal fuente de ingreso familiar la obtiene año a año de la venta de la cosecha de sus vegetales y ahora gracias a la iniciativa de su esposa también de la crianza y venta de pequeños animalitos.Este año desea incursionar en la venta de sus productos sin intermediarios para obtener mayores ganacias y empezar a adquirir experiencia a fin de asociar a sus vecinos para llevar a cabo este proyecto en beneficio de los centenares de familias de su amada ciudad. Para que este proyecto tenga buen término solicita vuestra ayuda a fin de adquirir mayor cantidad de abonos y fertilizantes que optimizarán el tamaño y nutrientes de sus sembríos.

loans.use: Purchase manure and natural fertilizer

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Upon the break up of her marriage, Carmen had to being a business to support her home. She decided to raise guinea pigs in the sheds she renovated. Due to the good feeding and constant care her mischievous little tenants have become the favorites in the community and now she is also sending them to her country’s capital to sell. She has the wish to improve the sheds in which she raises the guinea pigs so that they can grow with greater comfort and care.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

Carmen, a raíz de su ruptura matrimonial, tuvo que iniciar un negocio para el sostenimiento de su hogar y decidió criar cuyes en los galpones que acondicionó para esta labor; debido a la buena alimentación y constantes cuidados sus traviesos inquilinos han logrado convertirse en los favoritos de su comunidad y ahora también esta enviándolos a la capital de su país para su comercialización. Tiene el noble deseo de mejorar sus condiciones de crianza para que se puedan desarrollar con mayor comodidad.

loans.use: Renovate and improve sheds to raise guinea pigs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
The knowledge aquired from her parents and grandparents has contributed to Juana's work raising pigs and guinea pigs in a special space in her home. Juana's work in animal sales generates some income for her family. Additionally, her beloved husband contributes by planting large quantities of alfalfa for feeding those mischievous little animals. Juana would like to increase little by little the variety of her animals and breed them with this loan of $375.

Translated from Spanish by Maggie Messerschmidt, Kiva volunteer.

Los conocimientos que adquirió D. sus padres y abuelos han contribuido con el desempeño D. Juana. Ella se dedica a criar cerditos y cuyes en un espacio especial D. su hogar por la rentabilidad que genera su desempeño a su familia. Por otra parte su amado esposo contribuye con esta labor sembrando en grandes cantidades alfalfa para la alimentación D. estos traviesos animalitos. Se han propuesto ir incrementando poco a poco la variedad D. sus animalitos y tiene el noble propósito D. convertirse en la familia que agrupe a las mejores razas D. cada ejemplar.

loans.use: Increasing the variety of animals for breeding.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Yrma

texts.es:
When her husband made the decision to leave the city to work for a well-known business in their country, Yrma decided to begin working in embroidery at her beloved mother's workshop. With eagerness, and with the important help and advice of her dear children, little by little, she has been able to improve her technique and color combinations for her beautiful embroidery. Thanks to this initiative, business has increased, and she has moved her own workshop into her humble abode where her main associates are her two small children. With this loan of $775, she would like to buy cloth and thread for a her shop, to give work to many mothers who, like her, wish to put their efforts toward creating beautiful pieces.

Translated from Spanish by Maggie Messerschmidt, Kiva volunteer.

A raíz de la decisión de su esposo de salir de su ciudad para prestar servicios en una empresa reconocida de su país, Yrma decidió iniciar su labor de bordados en el taller de su querida madre, con mucho ahínco y con la importante ayuda y consejos de sus queridos hijos día a día ha ido mejorando su técnica y combinaciones de colores para sus bellos bordados, gracias a esta iniciativa las solicitudes se han incrementado y se ha mudado a su taller personal en su humilde morada en el que sus mejores socios son sus dos pequeños hijos. Tiene en mente instalar en el una fábrica para dar trabajo a muchas madres que como ella desean plasmar su buen gusto en bellos fustanes.

loans.use: Purchase of large quantity of materials, cloth and thread, for improving embroidery.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Cirilo

texts.es:
Cirilo is a humble farmer who each planting season puts the majority of his energies toward obtaining excellent products, with the help of his beloved spouse. The fruits of their land, potatoes of several varieties, are prepared for sale in community markets and for door-to-door sale with the important help of a tricycle cart that they have had for many years. Their purpose for this loan ($375) is to lease new cropfields in order to increase production and produce better yields of their product, the staple of their county, the potato.

Translated from Spanish by Maggie Messerschmidt, Kiva Volunteer.

Cirilo, es un humilde agricultor que a cada temporada de siembra pone la mayor cantidad de energías para obtener excelentes productos, con ayuda de su amada esposa, luego de obtener los frutos de sus fértiles tierras se preparan para comercializar sus papas de diversas clases en las ferias de su comunidad y también a domicilio con la importante ayuda de un triciclo que adquirieron hace muchos años.Tienen el noble propósito de incrementar su producción con el arrendamiento de nuevas tierras de cultivo a fin de convertirse en los mejores comercializadotes del producto bandera de su país “la papa”.

loans.use: Leasing land.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Suliana

texts.es:
Thanks to legacy of her parents and her grandparents, Suliana and her husband have been able to set up a small tailoring business. They got involved in this business with the help of their children who helped promote their work. They want to grow their business by offering new designs and novelties to their clients in the city.

El legado de sus padres y abuelos han hecho posible la instalación de un espacio de confección de ternos a Suliana y a su querido esposo. Se desenvuelven en este espacio con la ayuda y publicidad de sus queridos hijos y han decidido convertir a su pequeño establecimiento en el más popular con lo arreglos que han decidido incorporar y con las nuevas novedades que van a presentar a las personas de buen gusto y vestir en su ciudad.

loans.use: TO PURCHASE A GREATER VARIETY OF FABRICS FOR THEIR TAILORING BUSINESS.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Genoveva

texts.es: The experience of Genoveva's husband in putting together fireworks shows, motivated her to start promoting his business. Now she helps with each of his contracts and also contributes in the production and final arrangements of each show, including security to avoid any accidents. These fireworks shows are very popular in every village of their city. That's why Genoveva, with her excellent administrative skills, would like to grow the business and prepare for the requests from their clients who are getting ready for the festivals they will celebrate in this beautiful Peruvian valley. La experiencia del esposo de Genoveva, para fabricar espectáculos pirotécnicos han conducido a esta trabajadora madre ha introducirse y ser un especie de promotora de la labor de su querido esposo, ella asesora cada uno de sus contratos y también contribuye con la fabricación y arreglos finales de cada uno de los castillos que llevan a cabo, también está pendiente de las normas de seguridad y trata de supervisar a diario el cumplimiento de lo pactad a fin de evitar accidentes,Estos espectáculos son muy vistosos y agradables y no faltan en las actividades de cada pueblito de su ciudad, ella como excelente administradora desea incrementar su capital de trabajo a fin de prepararse con antelación a las solicitudes de sus exigentes clientes que están próximos a hacer las peticiones por las fechas festivas que celebrarán en este hermoso valle del Perú.

loans.use: TO PURCHASE THE SUPPLIES THEY WILL NEED FOR THEIR FIREWORKS SHOWS,  PREPARING IN ADVANCE FOR THE UPCOMING FESTIVALS.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa is a dedicated mother who takes advantage of the opportunities she has to improve the quality of life for her family. Before she worked selling newspapers, she used to sell clothing along with her husband in the markets of their community. Now, thanks to her initiative, she and her husband work in various businesses. She would like to increase their income by offering snacks such as crackers, sweets and sodas to the people who come by her news stand each day.

Rosa, es una abnegada madre que no desaprovecha las oportunidades que se le presentan con el propósito de mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia, antes de dedicarse a la venta de periódicos ofertaba semanalmente en compañía de su querido esposo diversas prendas de vestir en las feria de su comunidad, ahora gracias a su iniciativa ella y su esposo cuentan con actividades diversificadas. Tiene el deseo de mejorar los ingresos monetarios de su actual centro de trabajo ofertando también galletas, caramelos y bebidas gaseosas a las personas que transitan a diario por esta avenida.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE CRACKERS, SWEETS AND SODAS TO SELL FROM HER NEWSPAPER STAND, INCREASING HER INCOME BY OFFERING MORE PRODUCTS TO HER CUSTOMERS.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
Ana Maria is a hard working mother who actively contributes to the well being of her family by selling bread along a busy street in her city. She spends many hours at her small stand waiting for her customers. She realizes that with the excellent quality and customer service she gives, she can grow her business. She's decided to open a small shop where she can offer everyday grocery items as well as bread.

Ana María, es una trabajadora madre que contribuye de manera activa a mejorar las condiciones de vida de su amada familia a través de la venta de panes desde un establecimiento en la calle más concurrida de su ciudad.En este pequeño espacio permanece durante muchas horas en espera de sus clientes en todo momento. Se ha dado cuenta que con la excelente calidad de atención que brinda y a la acogida de sus clientes puede explotar aún más estas instalaciones y ha decidido implementar en el una bodega para además de ofertar panes vender artículos de primera necesidad.

loans.use: TO INVEST IN A SMALL SHOP WHERE SHE CAN EXPAND HER BUSINESS SELLING BREAD, TO INCLUDE EVERYDAY GROCERY ITEMS AS WELL.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
From the time he was very young, Juan has worked to survive. Coming from a very poor family, he learned everything he could about sewing and tailoring. Many years of work have enabled him to save for his own sewing tools. His wife has also contributed to the business. They are very pleased that the school season is arriving because just like in previous years, there will be requests to make more clothing.

Juan desde que era muy joven ha trabajado para poder sobrevivir, ya que proviene de una familia de condición muy humilde y esto le ha servido mucho para aprender todo sobre la confección de prendas a nivel industrial, muchos años de trabajo le han servido para ahorrar y comprar sus propias herramientas de trabajo, su fiel esposa contribuye con su buen desempeño y están muy contentos con la llegad de la época escolar ya que albergarán como en años anteriores las solicitudes de los padres de familia para confeccionar buzos y camisetas deportivas.

loans.use: TO PURCHASE GREATER QUANTITIES OF SEWING SUPPLIES AND MATERIAL FOR HIS TAILORING BUSINESS.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Hacia Al Futuro Group

texts.en:
Nadege O. is a cheerful young woman who lives with her three children (ages: 4, 1, 3 months) and earns a living by sewing and mending dresses and other types of clothing. With this loan she wants to buy new fabric and material in order to continue making these dresses for women in her community. She is very skilled, and can sew dresses very quickly and professionally. Her dream for the future is to have a steady business that will help provide money for her children. The biggest obstacle she faces right now is finding an affordable room or building to run her business out of.

Many women in this community have just completed paying back their first loan, and this will be their second loan, as is the case with Nadege. For the other women, this is there first opportunity to obtain credit in order to improve their lives and care for their families. Esperanza wants to thank all of the Kiva lenders that make it possible for us to continually extend credit to these women. God bless!

loans.use: To buy new materials for making dresses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Chicas De La Raza 2 Group

texts.es:
The group Chicas de la Raza 2 (Girls of Race) is made up of the following members: Elizabeth Margarita, Margarita Concepcion who sell clothing for men, women and children and Mrs. Maria Gabriela who learned as a young child how to makes sweets and traditional cakes from her grandmother in the region of San Cristobal de Las Casa, which she sells to established businesses in the center of town. She is 38 years old, the mother of four and with this loan she will invest in purchasing more flour, eggs and all other items necessary to continue fabricating her bakery items.

Translated from Spanish to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

EL GRUPO CHICAS DE LA RAZA 2 LO FORMAN: ELIZABTH MARGARITA, MARGARITA CONCEPCION QUE SE DEDICAN A LA VENTA DE ROPA PARA TODA LA FAMILIA Y DOÑA MARIA GABRIELA DESDE MUY PEQUEÑA APRENDIO DE SU ABUELA HACER DULCES Y PASTELES TRADICIONALES DE LA REGION DE LA CIUDAD DE SAN CRISTOBAL DE LAS CASAS, ENTREGA A LOS LOCALES COMERCIALES ESTABLECIDOS EN EL CENTRO DE LA CIUDAD. ELLA TIENE 38 AÑOS, CUATRO HIJOS, CON SU PRESTAMO INVERTIRA EN LA COMPRA DE HARINA, HUEVOS Y TODO LO NECESARIO PARA CONTINUAR CON LA PRODUCCION.

loans.use: To purchase flour and eggs to make cakes.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Alternativa Solidaria Chiapas (AlSol) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Chicas De La Raza 1 Group

texts.es:
Esmeralda del Carmen sells catalog products such as shoes, clothing, quilts and other home items. She began her business five years ago with some of her friends and neighbors and now many people know her and ask her for her products. She is 30 years old, the mother of two and belongs to a group called Chicas de la Raza (Girls of Race) 1, along with Mrs. Candelaria (who sells typical Mexican food), Teresa de Jesus ( who runs a grocery store) and Francisca de Jesus (who runs a butcher shop). With their loans, they will invest in the growth of their businesses and in this way be able to contribute to the household economy.

Translated from Spanish to English by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

ESMERALDA DEL CARMEN SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE PRODUCTOS POR CATALOGO COMO: ZAPATOS, ROPA, EDREDONES, ARTICULOS PARA EL HOGAR. SU NEGOCIO LO INICIO HACE CINCO AÑOS CON AMIGOS Y VECINOS, ACTUALMENTE MUCHA GENTE LA CONOCE Y PREGUNTAN POR LOS PRODUCTOS QUE VENDE. ELLA TIENE 30 AÑOS, DOS HIJOS Y PERTENECE AL GRUPO LLAMADO CHICAS DE LA RAZA 1 JUNTO CON DOÑA CANDELARIA (VENTA DE ZAPATOS POR CATALOGO), PETRA JOSEFA (VENTA DE FRUTAS Y VERDURAS), YULIANA DEL CARMEN (VENTA DE COMIDA TIPICA), TERESA DE JESUS (TIENDA DE ABARROTES) Y FRANCISCA DE JESUS (TIENE UNA CARNICERIA). CON SUS PRESTAMOS INVERTIRAN PARA EL CRECIMIENTO DE SUS NEGOCIOS Y DE ESTA FORMA CONTRIBUIR PARA LOS GASTOS DEL HOGAR.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of home products, clothing and shoes.

loans.name: Lupita

texts.es:
“It has been several months since I received my residence and now I would like to enlarge it a bit since the space that I have is very small. I know I will have to do a little at a time since my financial situation is very difficult. However, I will work so that I can have my house with more comforts and more space” I am requesting USD $500 to enlarge my residence.
Translated from Sapnish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.
“Hace algunos meses que me entregaron mi vivienda, ahora me gustaría ampliarla un poco ya que el espacio que tengo es muy pequeño, se que tendré que hacerlo poco a poco ya que la situación económica esta muy difícil, pero voy a trabajar para poder tener mi casa con más comodidades y más espacio” Solicito  $ 500.00 dlls para ampliar en mi vivienda.

loans.use: Construction of a room.

loans.name: Osbaldo

texts.es:
Osbaldo is the father of 2 children, 11 and 9, who are in school. He's long loved cars and motorcycles and he started a business buying and selling cars when he needed an income that would allow him to better support his family. He started it 7 years ago when he sold the family car for a good price and used the money to buy two cheaper cars that he later sold. He saw that this could be a good source of income with which he could provide for his family.

Osbaldo is now applying for a US$300 loan, to be repaid in 6 months, to pay off a loan on a motorcycle that he bought. With your support, Osbaldo can continue to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Osbaldo es padre de 2 hijos de 11 y 9 años que son estudiantes. Inicio el negocio de compra-venta de autos dado su gusto por los automóviles y motocicletas, ya que requería tener una fuente de ingresos que le permitiera sacar adelante a su familia. Esto lo inicio hace 7 años cuando vendió el carro familiar a un buen precio y con este dinero compro otros dos de menor recio que después vendió y vio que de esto era una buena fuente de ingresos con la que podría cubrir las necesidades de su familia.

Ahora solicita un crédito por US $300 que pagara en 6 meses para terminar de liquidar una motocicleta que adquirió. Con tu apoyo Osbaldo seguirá adelante.

loans.use: Buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.es:
Maria is divorced and has 3 children, 19, 14, and 9, all still in school. When her husband left her, she had to find a way to support her children and especially to be able to send them to school. Six years ago, she started selling cold drinks and food to the truckers who passed by on a local road. She found out from them that they needed a place to bath and wash and iron their clothes so she decided to offer those services. She now wants to buy used clothes to resell to her customers.

Maria is asking for a US$775 loan, to be repaid in 6 months, to buy used clothes for resale. With your help, this enterprising woman will be able to build on her success.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Ma. Guadalupe es divorciada y tiene 3 hijos de 19,14 y 9 años, todos ellos estudiantes.
